FXUS64 KMRX 052009
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
309 PM EST MON DEC 5 2011

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND TUESDAY)...RADAR INDICATING COVERAGE 
INCREASING ALONG OUR WESTERN ZONES ASSOCIATED WITH COLD FRONT WHICH 
IS EXPECTED TO TRACK THROUGH THE AREA TONIGHT AND TUESDAY. WILL KEEP 
CATEGORICAL POPS FOR TONIGHT AND TUESDAY. THE HEAVIEST RAIN SHOULD 
HOLD OFF UNTIL LATE THIS EVENING AND INTO TUESDAY MORNING. WITH THE 
CLOUDS AND RAIN OVER THE AREA...STAYED CLOSER TO COOLER MAV FOR 
TEMPERATURES.  

.LONG TERM...(TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY)...CONFIDENCE LOWER THAN 
AVERAGE FOR EARLY PART OF THE FORECAST...AS MODEL AGREEMENT AND RUN 
TO RUN CONSISTENCY NOT GOOD.  HOW STRONG SHORT WAVE THAT COMES 
ACROSS WED/EARLY WED NIGHT WILL BE STILL UNCERTAIN...BUT LOOKS LIKE 
A SURFACE WAVE WILL FORM ON THE FRONT TO OUR EAST AS THIS SHORT WAVE 
APPROACHES.  WILL HAVE TO RAISE POPS TO LIKELY AND CATEGORICAL FOR 
AT LEAST LATTER HALF OF TUE NIGHT INTO FIRST HALF OF WED NIGHT.  
ALSO...PRECIP TYPE BECOMES A CONCERN BY WED EVENING AS FREEZING 
LEVELS FALL...AT LEAST FOR THE HIGHER TERRAIN.  WHILE UNCERTAINTY 
LEVEL IS STILL HIGH AT THIS POINT...SOME SNOW ACCUMULATION APPEARS 
POSSIBLE AT LEAST IN THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS.  WILL MENTION IN HWO.  A 
DRY COLD FRONT FORECAST TO MOVE THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT WITH SOME 
CLOUDS...BUT OVERALL THE LATTER PART OF THE FORECAST PERIOD LOOKS TO 
BE FAIRLY UNEVENTFUL WITH MAINLY DRY CONDITIONS AND TEMPERATURES 
GENERALLY AROUND TO A BIT BELOW SEASONAL NORMS.

026 
FXUS64 KMRX 051505
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1005 AM EST MON DEC 5 2011

.DISCUSSION...RADAR INDICATING A FEW ECHOES TRACKING ACROSS MIDDLE 
TN. IT SHOULD TRACKING INTO THE CWA AS THE FRONT NEARS. IT SHOULD BE 
LATE IN THE AFTERNOON AND INTO THE EVENING HOURS BEFORE THE HEAVIER 
RAIN SHOULD ARRIVE. 850 JET SHOULD CONTINUE TO DECREASE THIS 
AFTERNOON. TEMPERATURES AND THE REST OF THE FORECAST ON TRACK. WILL 
UPDATE FORECAST TO REMOVE MORNING GROUP. NO OTHER CHANGES PLANNED. 

.PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY)...SHOWERS ASSOCIATED WITH THE 
COLD FRONT TO OUR WEST HAVE MOVED EAST TO ALONG AND WEST OF I-65 
THIS MORNING. MOSTLY MID TO HIGH CLOUDS ACROSS OUR FORECAST AREA
...ALTHO A LOWER CLOUD DECK HAS SPREAD INTO PARTS OF SE TN AND SW 
NC. LOW LEVEL JET AHEAD OF THE FRONT APPEARS TO BE AROUND 30 TO 35 
KNOTS PER RADAR WIND PROFILES AND 05/00Z UPPER AIR PLOTS...SO SOME 
GUSTY SE-S WINDS EARLY THIS MORNING IN THE HIGHER TERRAIN SPOTS.
RESULT OF THIS IS VERY MILD TEMPS IN THE UPPER 40S TO MID 50S TO 
START THE DAY.

PREVIOUS GRIDS LOOKED VERY GOOD FOR TIMING SHOWERS REACHING EAST TN 
LATER TODAY...THEN 90 TO 100 PERCENT POPS FOR TONIGHT AND TUESDAY AS 
COLD FRONT SLOWS OR STALLS BRIEFLY ACROSS THE APPALACHIANS. HEAVIER 
RAINS SHOULD BE TONIGHT...WHEN FRONTOGENETIC FORCING IS BEST OVER 
PLATEAU AND SE TN...PLUS AT LEAST WEAK UPPER LEVEL DIVERGENCE. 
MODELS SHOW MUCH WEAKENING AFTER 06Z TUESDAY...SO EVEN THOUGH 
SHOWERS LINGER INTO WEDNESDAY...RAIN AMOUNTS SHOULD FALL SHARPLY.
LOOKS LIKE A GENERAL 1 TO 2 INCH RAIN EVENT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT
...IN LINE WITH LATEST HPC QPF. 

INSTABILITY IS LACKING AND UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT IS MINIMAL...SO NO 
MENTION OF THUNDERSTORMS. OTHERWISE...NAM MOS HIGHS A LITTLE OUT OF 
REACH WITH GFS MAXES BETTER CHOICE FOR TODAY. SIMILAR MOS MINS 
ACCEPTED FOR TONIGHT...AND MOS HIGHS TUESDAY VERY REASONABLE.

.LONG TERM...(TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...SLOW MOVING COLD
FRONT WILL HAVE PROGRESSED TO NEAR THE APPALACHIAN CREST BY 00Z
WEDNESDAY. RAINFALL AMOUNTS WILL BE MUCH LOWER BEHIND THE FRONT
TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. UPPER LOW ON BACKSIDE OF SYSTEM WILL
ENHANCE PRECIPITATION WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND CONTINUE INTO THURSDAY.
FREEZING LEVELS DROP LOW ENOUGH FOR A SMALL AMOUNT OF SNOW LATE
WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND EARLY THURSDAY IN THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS. COOL
HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN THURSDAY NIGHT AND CONTINUES THROUGH THE
WEEKEND. A WEAK SYSTEM MAY BRING A FEW CLOUDS TO THE AREA FRIDAY
NIGHT AND EARLY SATURDAY OTHERWISE THE REGION WILL HAVE MOSTLY
FAIR SKIES AND BELOW NORMAL TEMPERATURES.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             64  51  58  45  51 /  60 100  90  50  50 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  64  50  59  44  52 /  40 100  90  70  50 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       60  48  56  43  51 /  40 100  90  50  50 
TRI CITIES AIRPORT, TN              61  48  59  43  52 /  30  90  90  70  50

.AVIATION...MID AND HIGH LEVEL CLOUDS IN PLACE OVER THE TAF SITES AS

EARLY THIS MORNING CREATES CONDITIONS ALMOST FOR LLWS AT CHA...BUT 
BEST ESTIMATE IS ONLY 25 KNOTS DIFFERENCE FROM SURFACE TO 2000 FT 
AGL...BASED ON WIND PROFILES FROM AREA RADARS.  SOME MIXING TO THE 
SURFACE IS ALSO NOTED AT BOTH CHA AND TYS...WHERE LOW LEVEL JET IS 
STRONGEST.

VFR CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED THROUGH THE PERIOD...WITH LOWER CIGS AND 
A FEW SHOWERS POSSIBLY REACHING INTO THE TAF SITES AFTER 00Z.  AS 
THE SYSTEM APPROACHES...THE PRESSURE GRADIENT WILL TIGHTEN AND WILL 
SEE WINDS BEGIN TO INCREASE SLIGHTLY THIS AFTERNOON.

&&

.MRX WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
NC...NONE.
TN...NONE.
VA...NONE.

&&

TG

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
320 PM EST SUN DEC 4 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT)...LONG POSITIVELY TILTED 
UPPER TROUGH BISECTS THE U.S. SW TO NE. AIRMASS WILL MODIFY TO ABOVE 
NORMAL BEGINNING MONDAY AND CONTINUE THROUGH SHORT TERM. COLD FRONT 
WILL MOVE SLOWLY THROUGH MRX CWA TUESDAY WITH LAYER RELATIVE 
HUMIDITY DROPPING OFF ON TUESDAY NIGHT. WIDESPREAD PRECIPITATION 
WILL ACCOMPANY THE FRONT. PERSISTENT RAIN WITH EMBEDDED SHOWERS CAN 
BE EXPECTED WITH THIS SYSTEM. ANTICIPATED RAINFALL RATES COULD LEAD 
TO SOME LOCALIZED FLOODING BUT COUNTYWIDE FLOODING NOT EXPECTED AT 
THIS TIME. ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES WILL CONTINUE WITH INITIAL COLD 
AIR ADVECTION BEHIND SHALLOW FRONT WEAK AT THIS TIME.  

.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...FRONT TRACKING THROUGH THE 
AREA ON WEDNESDAY. WILL CONTINUE WITH CHANCE POPS FOR WEDNESDAY. 
UPPER LOW TRACKING THROUGH THE AREA ON THURSDAY. THE GFS MAINTAINS 
MORE MOISTURE INTO THURSDAY. WILL GO WITH THE DRIER ECMWF AND ADD 
ONLY SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR THURSDAY. HIGH PRESSURE RETURNS BRINGING 
DRY WEATHER FOR FRIDAY THROUGH SUNDAY. STAYED NEAR MEX/HPC GUIDANCE 
FOR TEMPERATURES.

626 
FXUS64 KMRX 041653
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1145 AM EST SUN DEC 4 2011

.DISCUSSION...SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE SLOWLY WEAKENING OVER SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIANS. STATOCU DECK CONTINUES TO WORK NORTHWARD INTO SE TN/SW 
NC THIS AFTERNOON. NO UPDATE PLANNED AS AIRMASS GRADUALLY MOISTENS. 
SON 

SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...HIGH CLOUDS STREAMING ACROSS THE 
FORECAST AREA...PLUS SOME BREEZY SE-S WINDS OVER HIGHER 
TERRAIN...WERE KEEPING TEMPS UP FROM 24 HOURS AGO. EXCEPTIONS WERE 
SHELTERED VALLEYS SUCH AS MURPHY NC AND TRI WHERE 07Z TEMPS WERE AT 
OR JUST BELOW 32 DEGREES. THUS...MINS WILL ONCE AGAIN VARY BY AS 
MUCH AS 10 TO 20 DEGREES ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA.

TIME HEIGHTS AND SOUNDINGS SHOW THESE HIGH CLOUDS SHOULD REMAIN 
BROKEN TO NEARLY OVERCAST IN COVERAGE...SO SKY GRIDS WERE INCREASED 
SOME FOR TODAY. THE INCREASING CLOUDS FAVORS COOLER MOS HIGHS WHERE 
SLIGHT DIFFERENCES ARE NOTED. 

FOR TONIGHT...CLOUDS SHOULD CONTINUE TO THICKEN AHEAD OF THE SLOW 
MOVING TROUGH AND COLD FRONT. HOWEVER...CHANCE OF SHOWERS SEEMS 
QUITE LIMITED UNTIL TOWARD 12Z MONDAY...SO POPS WERE DROPPED UNTIL 
AFTER MIDNIGHT. KEPT SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR MAINLY FAR WRN COUNTIES 
FROM 06Z TO 12Z MONDAY. MINS TONIGHT SHOULD BE EVEN MILDER...MOSTLY 
40S. 

LONG TERM...(MONDAY THROUGH SATURDAY)...DEEP UPPER TROUGH SETS UP 
OVER THE CENTRAL STATES WITH DEEP SOUTHWEST FLOW THROUGH THE LOWER 
MS VALLEY...OHIO VALLEY AND THE LOWER TN VALLEYS MONDAY. HEAVY RAIN 
AXIS IS EXPECTED TO STAY WEST OF THE FORECAST AREA UNTIL MONDAY 
NIGHT OR TUESDAY MORNING. FRONT IS EXPECTED TO MOVE SLOWLY EAST WITH 
HEAVIER RAIN SHIFTING EAST BY TUESDAY NIGHT. GFS IS MUCH MORE 
AGGRESSIVE WITH RAINFALL AMOUNTS AND DEVELOPS WAVE ALONG COLD FRONT 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT INTO THURSDAY. WITH DEEP SOUTHWEST FLOW TOTAL 
RAINFALL AMOUNTS MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY MIGHT REACH 2 TO 4 INCHES 
WHICH COULD PRODUCE SOME LOCALIZED FLOODING ESPECIALLY IN AREAS THAT 
RECEIVED HEAVY RAINFALL ALMOST A WEEK AGO. PREFER MORE PROGRESSIVE 
NAM...CANADIAN AND ECMWF TO GFS WHICH BRING SYSTEM THROUGH BY 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT. TEMPERATURES WILL BE MILD MONDAY THROUGH TUESDAY 
NIGHT AND THEN MUCH COOLER BEHIND THE FRONT WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT COLDER AIR MOVES IN CHANGING THE PRECIPITATION TO 
SNOW ACROSS MAINLY THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS BEFORE ENDING. ONLY MINOR 
ACCUMULATIONS ARE EXPECTED. RIDGING ALOFT WILL BRING DRY WEATHER TO 
THE REGION THURSDAY THROUGH SATURDAY. &&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             60  48  65  52  58 /  10  20  40  80  80 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  59  43  63  51  60 /   0  10  30  70  80 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       60  45  62  50  59 /   0  20  30  80  80 
TRI CITIES AIRPORT, TN              61  39  60  46  62 /   0  10  20  60  80

595 
FXUS64 KMRX 032007
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
253 PM EST SAT DEC 3 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND SUNDAY)...AIRMASS WILL SLOWLY MODIFY 
THROUGH THE PERIOD AS HIGH PRESSURE WEAKENS TOWARD THE EAST. HIGH 
LEVEL CLOUDS WILL STREAM ACROSS THE AREA. MOISTURE WILL LOWER TO THE 
MID LEVELS ON SUNDAY. SOME LOW LEVEL CLOUDS WILL BEGIN TO DEVELOP 
ACROSS SOUTHERN PORTIONS OF THE MRX CWA BY SUNDAY AFTERNOON. ABOVE 
NORMAL TEMPERATURES WILL BE MODERATED BY CLOUD COVER. LEANED TOWARD 
THE WARM SIDE OF GUIDANCE.

.LONG TERM (SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY)...MAIN EVENT IS DEEP 
UPPER TROUGH MOVING SLOWLY ACROSS THE MID-SECTION OF THE NATION 
TOWARD THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY 
NIGHT. MODELS SHOW STRONG DEEP SOUTHWEST FLOW DEVELOPING OVER THE 
TENNESSEE VALLEY AND SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS WITH UNSEASONABLY HIGH PW 
VALUES. SERIES OF JET STREAKS WILL ENHANCE LIFT FOR TUESDAY AND 
WEDNESDAY WITH THE FORECAST AREA UNDER PERIODS OF STRONG DIVERGENCE 
ALOFT AND AGEOSTROPHIC CIRCULATION FORCING.

THE STRONG AGEOSTROPHIC VERTICAL CIRCULATION WILL HELP ENHANCE THE 
FRONTOGENETIC FORCING ENHANCING PRECIPITATION ACROSS THE AREA BOTH 
TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY. RAINFALL OF 3 TO 5 INCHES WILL BE POSSIBLE...
ESPECIALLY FOR THE PLATEAU...SOUTHEAST TENNESSEE...AND SOUTHWEST 
NORTH CAROLINA. 

SYSTEM WILL MOVE EAST OF THE AREA FOR WEDNESDAY NIGHT WITH COLDER 
AIR CHANGING THE PRECIPITATION TO SNOW ACROSS THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS 
BEFORE ENDING. ONLY MINOR ACCUMULATIONS EXPECTED.

FAIRLY WEAK RIDGING WILL DOMINATE THE REST OF THE EXTENDED FORECAST

407 
FXUS64 KMRX 031602
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1100 AM EST SAT DEC 3 2011

.DISCUSSION...FORECAST ON TRACK. NO UPDATE PLANNED. SON

SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...
SURFACE RIDGE ACROSS THE APPALACHIANS PLUS RIDGING ALOFT OVER THE
SE STATES...WILL KEEP THE FORECAST AREA DRY WELL BEYOND THE NEXT
24 HOURS. TRANSIENT HIGH CLOUDS THIS MORNING MAY THIN OUT BY LATE
MORNING INTO THE AFTERNOON. THUS...PLENTY OF SUNSHINE TO REACH AT
LEAST A BLEND OF SIMILAR MOS HIGHS FOR TODAY. GFS MOS WAS FAIRLY
CLOSE ON FRIDAY HIGHS...SO I STAYED VERY MUCH IN LINE. SO FAR...NOT
SEEING MUCH IF ANY PATCHY AREAS OF FOG OR FREEZING FOG DEVELOP.
PLAN TO KEEP THIS FOG OUT OF THE FORECAST AND WILL COVER IN THE
SHORT TERM FORECAST IF ANY FOG DOES DEVELOP PRIOR TO DAYBREAK.

FOR TONIGHT...ANOTHER TRICKY MIN TEMP FORECAST GIVEN THE VERY LIGHT 
WINDS IN SHELTERED VALLEYS...AND POSSIBLE INCREASING CLOUDS LATE 
TONIGHT. FORECASTED MINS IN A SIMILAR PATTERN TO WHAT IS BEING 
OBSERVED THIS MORNING...WITH ABOUT A 15 DEGREE OR SO DIFFERENCE
FROM VALLEYS TO HIGHER TERRAIN WHERE LIGHT SOUTH WINDS ARE A
FACTOR.

LONG TERM...(SUNDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...STRONG RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE 
AT SURFACE AND ALOFT WILL BE ANCHORED ALONG THE EAST COAST SUNDAY 
WITH SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT BRINGING ABUNDANT MOISTURE INTO THE LOWER 
MS AND LOWER TN VALLEYS TO THE WEST OF THE CWA. CLOUDS WILL 
GRADUALLY INCREASE FROM SOUTHWEST TO NORTHEAST WITH WINDS INCREASING 
FROM THE SOUTH. NO RAIN IS EXPECTED. SUNDAY NIGHT RIDGING SHOULD 
HOLD WITH A FEW SHOWERS ON THE PLATEAU AND SOUTHERN VALLEY BUT DRY 
ELSEWHERE. LOWS WARMER IN THE 40S. MONDAY BASIC UPPER FLOW STILL 
MAINLY SOUTHWEST WITH RAIN CONTINUING OVER THE OHIO VALLEY AND 
WESTERN TN VALLEY AND ONLY A FEW HUNDREDTHS MAKING IT INTO EAST TN. 
MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY FRONT FINALLY GETS A PUSH EAST WITH SHOWERS 
BECOMING LIKELY. THINK RAINFALL AMOUNTS MONDAY NIGHT WILL BE LIGHT 
WITH SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL HOLDING OFF NOW UNTIL TUESDAY AND TUESDAY 
NIGHT. TOTAL AMOUNTS NOW MAY ONLY BE AROUND 1 TO 2 INCHES BEFORE 
SYSTEM PULLS OUT WEDNESDAY NIGHT. TEMPERATURES STAY WARM TUESDAY 
AHEAD OF FRONT WITH HIGHS IN THE 50S. MUCH COOLER WEDNESDAY BEHIND 
FRONT WITH CHANCE OF SNOW WEDNESDAY NIGHT. HIGHER PRESSURE BUILDS IN 
THURSDAY AND CONTINUES THROUGH THE END OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             63  37  60  48  63 /   0   0  10  20  40 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  60  35  60  44  63 /   0   0  10  10  30 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       61  36  59  45  62 /   0   0  10  20  40

THE LOWER MS AND LOWER TN VALLEYS TO THE WEST OF THE CWA. CLOUDS
WILL GRADUALLY INCREASE FROM SOUTHWEST TO NORTHEAST WITH WINDS
INCREASING FROM THE SOUTH. NO RAIN IS EXPECTED. SUNDAY NIGHT
RIDGING SHOULD HOLD WITH A FEW SHOWERS ON THE PLATEAU AND SOUTHERN
VALLEY BUT DRY ELSEWHERE. LOWS WARMER IN THE 40S. MONDAY BASIC
UPPER FLOW STILL MAINLY SOUTHWEST WITH RAIN CONTINUING OVER THE
OHIO VALLEY AND WESTERN TN VALLEY AND ONLY A FEW HUNDREDTHS MAKING
IT INTO EAST TN. MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY FRONT FINALLY GETS A PUSH
EAST WITH SHOWERS BECOMING LIKELY. THINK RAINFALL AMOUNTS MONDAY
NIGHT WILL BE LIGHT WITH SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL HOLDING OFF NOW UNTIL
TUESDAY AND TUESDAY NIGHT. TOTAL AMOUNTS NOW MAY ONLY BE AROUND 1
TO 2 INCHES BEFORE SYSTEM PULLS OUT WEDNESDAY NIGHT. TEMPERATURES
STAY WARM TUESDAY AHEAD OF FRONT WITH HIGHS IN THE 50S. MUCH COOLER
WEDNESDAY BEHIND FRONT WITH CHANCE OF SNOW WEDNESDAY NIGHT. HIGHER
PRESSURE BUILDS IN THURSDAY AND CONTINUES THROUGH THE END OF THE
FORECAST PERIOD.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             63  37  60  48  63 /   0   0  10  20  40 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  60  35  60  44  63 /   0   0  10  10  30 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       61  36  59  45  62 /   0   0  10  20  40

553 
FXUS64 KMRX 022017
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
309 PM EST FRI DEC 2 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT)...DRY SHORT WAVE MOVING 
EAST THROUGH THE CENTRAL APPALACHIANS EARLY TONIGHT. SURFACE HIGH 
PRESSURE REMAINS OVER THE MID SOUTH AND THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS. 
BELOW NORMAL TEMPERATURES TONIGHT. LATE NIGHT FOG WILL DEVELOP OVER 
WATERWAYS AND CONTINUE INTO THE MORNING HOURS. SATURDAY WARM UP GETS 
GOING WITH SOME HIGH CLOUDS STREAMING ACROSS THE AREA. SURFACE RIDGE 
SHIFTS EAST OF THE APPALACHIANS ON SUNDAY WITH CONTINUED WARMING AND 
INCREASED HIGH LEVEL CLOUD COVER. REMOVED POPS FOR SUNDAY AND BACKED 
OFF ON PRECIPITATION SUNDAY NIGHT AS BEST FORCING REMAINS WEST OF 
THE AREA. WARM MIN TEMPS BY MONDAY MORNING AND WENT A BIT ABOVE 
GUIDANCE.   


.LONG TERM (MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...BY THIS TIME...THE HEAVY 
RAIN-MAKER SHOULD BE ENCROACHING ON THE WESTERN CWA. THE QPF 
FORECAST IN THE GRIDS ONLY GOES THROUGH MONDAY...WHEREAS THE 
HEAVIEST RAINS LOOK TO BE MOVING IN MONDAY NIGHT AND INTO 
TUESDAY...WITH CURRENT MODEL TIMING...AND CONTINUING THROUGH 
WEDNESDAY OR SO.  LOOKING LIKE PRECIP AXIS WILL BE ORIENTED SSW-NNE. 

PRESENTLY TOTALS IN OUR AREA LOOK LIKE THEY WILL BE HEAVIEST IN THE 
WEST...WITH 2-3 INCH TOTALS IN THE WESTERN AREAS/PLATEAU ETC...1-2 
INCH VALUES IN THE HEART OF THE TENN VALLEY...AROUND AN INCH 
EAST...AND LESS THAN AN INCH IN THE TYPICALLY RAIN-SHADOWED AREAS OF 
THE NORTHEASTERN CWA.  WE'LL HAVE TO WATCH FOR TRENDS...AS MUCH 
HEAVIER AMOUNTS ARE FORECAST TO OUR WEST.

LOOKING AT THE AIR MASS IN THIS EVENT...PRECIPITABLE WATER VALUES 
ARE FORECAST TO BE 1.2 TO 1.3 INCHES OVER MOST OF THE FORECAST 
AREA...EXCEPT AROUND 1.1 INCHES IN THE NORTHEAST.  THIS TRANSLATES 
TO AROUND THE 90TH PERCENTILE ON DECEMBER PRECIPITABLE WATER 
CLIMATOLOGY...JUST BELOW THE 2 STANDARD DEVIATIONS THRESHOLD.  THIS 
IS ON-PAR WITH THE AXIS OVER WESTERN AND MIDDLE TENN...JUST THAT THE 
AXIS OF RAIN IS EXPECTED TO BE OVER E TENN FOR A MUCH SHORTER 
DURATION.

THIS SYSTEM LOOKS TO BE WARM THROUGHOUT ALL OF THE 
PRECIPITATION...AND THE MOISTURE CLEARS OUT SO QUICKLY...THAT IT 
LOOKS LIKE THERE WON'T BE ANY POST-FRONTAL UPSLOPE SNOWS IN THE 
MOUNTAINS AT THE END OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

WENT CLOSE TO GUIDANCE ON TEMPS...FRONTAL TIMING AND PRECIP WILL 
DICTATE LARGER DEVIATIONS.   WITH SLOWER MOVEMENT EXPECTED...FOR 
MONDAY MAX TEMPS...WARMED UP EASTERN HALF ABOVE GUIDANCE...WITH 
SEVERAL DEGREES WARMER IN TYPICAL DOWNSLOPE AREAS IN NE TN.
KEPT MONDAY NIGHT/TUESDAY MORNING LOWS QUITE MILD OVER MOST OF THE 
AREA...CONSIDERING WARM AIR MASS AND CLOUD COVER.



&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

OAK RIDGE, TN                       31  61  36  59  46 /   0   0  10  10  20

282 
FXUS64 KMRX 021539
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1040 AM EST FRI DEC 2 2011

.DISCUSSION...FORECAST ON TRACK. FOG SLOW TO BURN OFF BUT WILL SOON.

SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...A RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE 
REGION WILL PROVIDE DRY WEATHER WITH TEMPS WARMING TO ABOUT 6 TO 8 
DEGREES ABOVE SEASONAL NORMALS. PLENTY OF SUNSHINE...AFTER SOME 
PATCHY AREAS OF FOG/FREEZING FOG EARLY THIS MORNING.

THE DRY AIR MASS WITH MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES AND LIGHT WINDS FAVORS THE 
COOLER GFS MINS TONIGHT...ESPECIALLY OUTSIDE OF THE WESTERN MOST 
AREAS AND HIGHER TERRAIN.

LONG TERM...(SATURDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE 
WILL CONTINUE OVER THE REGION SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT. SUNDAY 
NEXT DEVELOPING SYSTEM MOVES INTO LOWER MS AND OH VALLEYS. MODELS 
SLOW SYSTEM DOWN AND KEEP IT MAINLY TO THE WEST THROUGH SUNDAY 
NIGHT. MOISTURE GRADUALLY INCREASES SUNDAY AND SUNDAY NIGHT. MONDAY 
AND TUESDAY RAIN BECOMES LIKELY WITH FRONT OVER THE FORECAST AREA 
TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY. RAINFALL AMOUNTS MAY REACH AROUND THREE 
INCHES ACROSS WESTERN SECTIONS BY 00Z WEDNESDAY. WITH SATURATED 
CONDITIONS FROM THIS WEEK THERE WILL BE A RISK FOR RENEWED FLOODING. 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE ABOVE NORMAL SATURDAY AND SUNDAY AND THEN LOWER 
DURING THE DAY WITH CLOUDS AND RAIN. THERE IS A CHANCE OF A LITTLE 
SNOW TUESDAY NIGHT AND EARLY WEDNESDAY. HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN 
THURSDAY.
&&

SHOWERS ESPECIALLY HIGHER TERRAIN ON TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY. 
HIGH PRESSURE RETURNS PROVING DRY WEATHER FOR THURSDAY. STAYED NEAR 
MEX/HPC GUIDANCE FOR TEMPERATURES.

058 
FXUS64 KMRX 011545
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1045 AM EST THU DEC 1 2011

.DISCUSSION...FORECAST ON TRACK. NO UPDATE PLANNED. SON

SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...STRONG HIGH PRESSURE IN CONTROL 
THIS SHORT TERM FOR QUIET WEATHER WITH CLEAR SKIES AND LIGHT WINDS.  
WEAK WARM ADVECTION DEVELOPING OVER THE AREA COUPLED WITH ABUNDANT 
SUNSHINE TODAY WILL BEGIN A WARMING TREND...ALLOWING HIGHS TO REACH 
INTO THE 50S ACROSS MUCH OF THE MRX CWA THIS AFTERNOON.

LONG TERM...(FRIDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...PERIOD WILL START OUT 
FAIRLY TRANQUIL AS UPPER RIDGE AND SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE WILL BE IN 
CONTROL.  MODELS IN DECENT AGREEMENT IN BRINGING PRECIP AHEAD OF THE 
NEXT FRONTAL SYSTEM INTO OUR AREA LATE SUNDAY OR SUNDAY NIGHT...BUT 
MODELS DIFFER SIGNIFICANTLY IN HANDLING THE PROGRESSION OF THIS 
SYSTEM THROUGH OUR AREA.  CMC QUITE PROGRESSIVE...ECMWF VERY SLOW AS 
IT CUTS OFF AN UPPER LOW TO OUR WEST...AND GFS IS SOMEWHERE IN 
BETWEEN. GIVEN POOR MODEL AGREEMENT AND RUN TO RUN CONSISTENCY 
FORECAST CONFIDENCE IS LOWER THAN AVERAGE FOR LATTER PART OF THE 
PERIOD.  FOR NOW WILL LEAN TOWARD THE COMPROMISE GFS AND JUST DELAY 
THE EXIT OF THE PRECIP ABOUT 12 HOURS LATER THAN PREVIOUS FORECAST. 
WILL CARRY HIGHEST POPS MONDAY AND INTO MONDAY NIGHT...AS HIGHEST 
CONFIDENCE FOR PRECIP DURING THOSE PERIODS.   COLDER AIR ON THE 
BACKSIDE OF THIS SYSTEM MAY BRING A FEW SNOW SHOWERS ESPECIALLY 
HIGHER TERRAIN BY TUESDAY OR TUESDAY NIGHT.  


&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             57  32  61  34  63 /   0   0   0   0   0

313 
FXUS64 KMRX 301944
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
245 PM EST WED NOV 30 2011

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND THURSDAY)...SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE WILL
BUILD IN FROM THE WEST. LOW LEVELS WILL CONTINUE TO DRY OUT. 
DECREASED CLOUD COVER...LOWER HUMIDITIES AND LIGHT WINDS WILL ALLOW 
FOR GOOD COOLING OVERNIGHT. WEAK LOW LEVEL COLD AIR ADVECTION IS 
SHORT LIVED AS WARM AIR ADVECTION SLOWLY RETURNS ON THURSDAY. 
AFTERNOON TEMPERATURES WILL APPROACH NORMAL. 

.LONG TERM...(THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...GENERALLY DRY 
WEATHER REGIME WITH SLOWLY MODERATING TEMPS IN STORE THROUGH MOST OF 
THE WEEKEND AS UPPER RIDGE BUILDS INTO THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN 
REGION. NEXT SYSTEM APPROACHES THE AREA BY LATE SUNDAY. MEDIUM-RANGE 
MODELS ARE IN REASONABLY GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THE ONSET TIMING OF 
PRECIP ASSOCIATED WITH THIS SYSTEM...BUT DIFFER PROFOUNDLY ON THE 
PROGRESSION THROUGH THE REGION AS THE EUROPEAN MODEL DEPICTS A MUCH 
MORE AMPLIFIED UPPER TROUGH THAN THE GFS WHICH PUSHES THE SURFACE 
FRONT THROUGH MUCH SOONER. GFS FORESTALLS FRONTAL BOUNDARY AS UPPER 
FLOW REMAINS SOUTHWESTERLY BEFORE FINALLY PUSHING THE BOUNDARY 
THROUGH BY LATE TUESDAY. MOST GEFS ENSEMBLE MEMBERS ROUGHLY SPLIT 
THE DIFFERENCE AND ARE PREFERRED. DRY ALBEIT COOLER WEATHER RETURNS 
BY LATE IN THE LONG TERM. FOR TEMPS...GENERALLY DID NOT DEVIATE MUCH 
FROM MAV/MEX GUIDANCE.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  28  55  29  59  29 /   0   0   0   0   0

FXUS64 KMRX 301501
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1000 AM EST WED NOV 30 2011

.DISCUSSION...MINOR UPDATE TO TODAYS FORECAST. RAISED DEW POINTS UP
A FEW DEGREES EARLY TODAY. LOWERED MAX TEMPS A DEGREE. LIGHT 
PRECIPITATION TAPERING OFF OVER NE AREAS THIS MORNING. CLOUDS WILL 
BEGIN TO BREAK ALONG WESTERN AREA THIS AFTERNOON. SON

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION:
SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...UPPER LOW HAS EXITED THE SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIAN REGION WITH ONLY A FEW POCKETS OF DRIZZLE OR FLURRIES 
REMAINING OVER THE AREA.  THEREFORE...THE SNOW ADVISORY WILL BE 
CANCELLED.  THE REMAINING PRECIP WILL END THIS MORNING AS HIGH 
PRESSURE BUILDS IN.  THE RESULT WILL BE CLEARING SKIES AND 
DECREASING WINDS.  WITH COOL AIR IN PLACE...HIGHS WILL STRUGGLE INTO 
THE 40S THIS AFTERNOON AND DROP INTO THE 20S TONIGHT.

LONG TERM...(THURSDAY THROUGH TUESDAY)...MODELS IN ARE IN FAIRLY 
GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THE SYNOPTIC PATTERN FOR THE LONG TERM 
PERIOD...SO BETTER THAN AVERAGE FORECAST CONFIDENCE. UPPER 
RIDGE/SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE WILL DOMINATE THE FIRST PART OF THE 
PERIOD.  UPPER TROUGH WILL DIG TO OUR WEST AND THEN SHIFT EAST FOR 
THE SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY TIME FRAME...BRINGING A COLD FRONT 
THROUGH THE AREA.  EXACT TIMING OF FRONT STILL UNCERTAIN THAT FAR 
OUT AND LOOKS LIKE FRONT MAY BE SLOW TO PUSH THROUGH...SO WILL CARRY 
POPS SUNDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH TUESDAY WITH HIGHEST CHANCES MONDAY.  
MAY BE SOME SNOW SHOWERS BY LATE MONDAY NIGHT OR TUESDAY AT LEAST 
FOR HIGHER TERRAIN ON THE BACK SIDE OF THIS SYSTEM AS COLDER AIR 
PUSHES IN.   


&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION

905 PM EST TUE NOV 29 2011

.DISCUSSION...CYCLONIC FLOW CONTINUES OVER THE REGION WITH LOW

DOWN WITH 30/00Z UPPER AIR PLOTS SHOWING 850 MBS TEMPS -4 TO -5 DEGS
CELSIUS ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. SURFACE TO LOW LEVEL FLOW IS 
MOSTLY SW-W NOT REALLY AN IDEAL SET UP FOR UPSLOPE FLOW TO ENHANCE 
ANY SNOW ACCUMULATIONS. HOWEVER...MOISTURE IS STILL RATHER PLENTIFUL 
PER 30/00Z OHX/RNK SOUNDINGS...AND RADAR CONTINUES TO TRACK LIGHT 
SNOW MOVING SE FROM SE KY. THESE ECHOES WILL PASS ACROSS SW VA WHERE 
50 PERCENT POPS COULD BE INCREASED SLIGHTLY FOR THE NEXT FEW HOURS. 

MAY MAKE THAT SLIGHT CHANGE IN A LATE EVENING UPDATE. OTHERWISE...
PREVIOUS FORECAST GRIDS LOOK GOOD...AS DO THE VERY LIGHT SNOW ACCUMS 
MENTIONED IN THE WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY AREAS. I WILL KEEP THE 
ADVISORY GOING OVERNIGHT...BUT NEXT SHIFT SHOULD BE ABLE TO LET IT 
EXPIRE.

776 
FXUS64 KMRX 292320
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
620 PM EST TUE NOV 29 2011

.AVIATION...CIRCULATION AROUND THE SLOWLY EXITING LOW PRESSURE 
SYSTEM IS SPREADING SOME SPOTTY LIGHT PRECIPITATION FROM MIDDLE TN 
TO NEAR CHA VICINTY...WHILE A LARGER AREA OF LIGHT RAIN OR SNOW 
(POSSIBLY BRIEFLY MIXED WITH SLEET) CONTINUES TO TRACK NE OVER MUCH 
OF NE TN AND SW VA. DOUBTFUL IF THIS IS MUCH MORE THAN TRACE TO A 
FEW HUNDREDTHS OF AN INCH ACCUMULATION.

THE COLD AIR FLOWING IN AND LINGERING MOISTURE SHOULD SET THE STAGE 
FOR AT LEAST MVFR CONDTIONS OVERNIGHT...WOULD BE IFR FOR SURE IF NOT 
FOR DECENT MIXING FROM SW-W SURFACE AND LOW LEVEL WINDS.

LOOK FOR MUCH IMPROVEMENT DURING THE DAY WEDNESDAY WITH CLEARING 
SKIES ALL AREAS BY EARLY AFTERNOON.

PREVIOUS FORECAST DISCUSSION FOLLOWS...

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY)...UPPER LOW HAS NOW MOVED OVER 
THE FORECAST AREA WITH LIGHT RAIN AND SNOW THIS AFTERNOON ACROSS 
MUCH OF THE AREA. DOPPLER RADAR SHOWING COVERAGE SCATTERED IN THE 
VALLEYS WITH A LITTLE MORE COVERAGE IN THE EASTERN MOUNTAINS AT THIS 
TIME. WINDS HAVE BEEN MOSTLY SW ACROSS THE NE HALF OF THE FORECAST 
AREA AND THERE HAVE BEEN SOME BREAKS IN THE CLOUDS. TEMPERATURES 
TODAY HAVE BEEN NEARLY STEADY IN THE UPPER 30S TO LOWER 40S LOWER 
ELEVATIONS TO THE LOWER AND MIDDLE 30S HIGHER ELEVATIONS OF THE 
PLATEAU AND MOUNTAINS. NO SNOWFALL ACCUMULATION HAS OCCURRED AT 
LOWER ELEVATIONS TODAY. ON THE PLATEAU AMOUNTS TO ONE INCH OR SO 
WERE OBSERVED EARLIER TODAY. 

IN THE HIGHER MOUNTAINS ABOVE 3000 FEET...LIGHT ACCUMULATIONS ARE 
LIKELY LATE TODAY AND SHOULD CONTINUE OVERNIGHT. WILL CONTINUE 
SNOWFALL ADVISORY WITH NO CHANGES IN EXPIRATION OR AREA. LOWS 
TONIGHT SHOULD DROP TO NEAR FREEZING IN THE LOWER ELEVATIONS WITH 
LITTLE TO NO SNOW ACCUMULATION. ON WEDNESDAY AS UPPER LOW PULLS 
FARTHER AWAY...SKIES WILL BEGIN TO CLEAR IN THE VALLEYS...BUT 
LINGERING SNOW SHOWERS WILL CONTINUE NE AND EASTERN MOUNTAINS FOR A 
FEW HOURS IN THE MORNING. HIGHS WEDNESDAY WILL BE A FEW DEGREES 
WARMER THAN TODAY CENTRAL AND SOUTH...BUT STILL COLD NORTH WITH 
LINGERING CLOUDS AND PRECIPITATION.

.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY)...MODELS ARE IN GOOD 
AGREEMENT WITH THE SYNOPTIC PATTERN THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIOD... 
AND REVEAL TRANQUIL CONDITIONS AND SEASONABLY MILD TEMPS UNTIL EARLY 
NEXT WEEK. A WEAK COLD FRONT IS PROGGED TO MOVE THROUGH THE FORECAST 
AREA LATE THURSDAY NIGHT/EARLY FRIDAY MORNING...BUT LIMITED MOISTURE 
WITH THIS FRONT SHOULD PREVENT ANY PRECIP. ANOTHER STRONGER COLD 
FRONT IS THEN PROGGED TO MOVE ACROSS THE TN RIVER VALLEY SUNDAY 
NIGHT INTO MONDAY...BRINGING THE NEXT CHANCE FOR RAIN AS A DEEP 
UPPER-LEVEL TROUGH DEVELOPS OVER THE WESTERN HALF OF THE NATION. AS 
FOR TEMPS...WILL GENERALLY TREND TOWARDS THE GFS GUIDANCE NUMBERS 
THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIOD...WHICH ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THE 
ENSEMBLE MEANS.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN   34  46  27  57  29 /  20  10   0   0   0 
KNOXVILLE AIRPORT, TN     33  45  26  55  28 /  30  10   0   0   0 
OAK RIDGE, TN             33  45  26  55  28 /  30  10   0   0   0

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1107 AM EST TUE NOV 29 2011

.DISCUSSION...UPPER LEVEL LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM HAS NOW MOVED OVER
EAST TN AND EASTERN KY THIS MORNING. AREA RADARS STILL INDICATING
LIGHT RAIN AND SNOW CIRCULATING AROUND THE SYSTEM. EARLIER REPORTS
FROM THIS MORNING SHOWED SOME SNOW FLURRIES AND SHOWERS WERE
OCCURRING OVER THE PLATEAU COUNTIES AND ALSO IN THE HIGHER PARTS OF
THE SMOKIES. ACCUMULATIONS UP TO ONE INCH OCCURRED ON GRASSY
SURFACES ON THE SOUTHERN PLATEAU. WILL UPDATE WINTER WEATHER
ADVISORY AS SNOW DEVELOPS ACROSS THE MOUNTAINS STILL EXPECTING A
FEW INCHES LATER TODAY AND TONIGHT. TEMPERATURES SHOULD BE NEARLY
STEADY OR DROP AS COLDER AIR ON BACK SIDE OF UPPER LOW MOVES IN.

SIGNIFICANT CHANGES TO FORECAST.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
303 AM EST TUE NOV 29 2011

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...UPPER LOW WILL TRACK ACROSS THE 
AREA TODAY...THEN PULL AWAY TO THE NORTHEAST TONIGHT.  LIGHT PRECIP 
ALREADY MOVING INTO SOUTHWESTERN ZONES...AND SHOULD MOVE ACROSS THE 
ENTIRE AREA TODAY.  WILL CARRY LIKELY TO CAT POPS TODAY...WITH 
LIKELY IN EASTERN MOUNTAINS TONIGHT WITH SLIGHT CHANCE TO CHANCE 
ELSEWHERE.  PRECIP TYPE SHOULD BE MAINLY SNOW HIGHER 
ELEVATIONS...WITH RAIN POSSIBLY MIXING WITH SOME WET SNOW ELSEWHERE 
TODAY AND CHANGING TO SNOW SHOWERS TONIGHT.  EXPECT ACCUMULATION 
ONLY IN THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS...AND WILL ISSUE A WINTER WEATHER 
ADVISORY FOR HIGHER ELEVATIONS OF THE EASTERN TN MOUNTAINS FROM 
MONROE COUNTY NORTHWARD. 

.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY THROUGH MONDAY)...UPPER LOW PULLING AWAY FROM 
THE REGION ON WEDNESDAY...ALLOWING A FEW LINGERING RAIN AND SNOW 
SHOWER DURING THE FIRST HALF OF THE DAY.  AT THIS POINT...MOISTURE 
BECOMES QUITE LIMITED AND LITTLE TO NO ACCUMULATIONS ARE EXPECTED 
OVER HIGHER ELEVATIONS.  HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN FOR THURSDAY 
THROUGH SATURDAY FOR DRY CONDITIONS AND A WARMING TREND.  THE NEXT 
SYSTEM MOVES IN LATE IN THE EXTENDED.  MODELS DIFFER SIGNIFICANTLY 
IN TIMING...SO WILL KEEP POPS IN FOR SUNDAY THROUGH MONDAY WITH 
HIGHEST CHANCE COMPROMISING ON SUNDAY NIGHT.

762 
FXUS64 KMRX 282036
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
335 PM EST MON NOV 28 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND TUESDAY)...SLOW MOVING UPPER LOW STILL OVER 
MS THIS AFTERNOON. COLDER TEMPERATURES SW OF SURFACE LOW OVER MIDDLE 
AND EAST TN ARE IN THE UPPER 40S...WHILE OUT AHEAD OF THE SURFACE 
LOW WHERE WINDS ARE EAST AND RAINFALL HAS BEEN INTERMITTENT...TEMPS 
ARE STILL IN THE MID 60S. WINDS WILL STILL BE SOMEWHAT STRONG FROM 
THE SMOKY MOUNTAINS NORTH TO VIRGINIA THROUGH MOST OF THE EVENING. 
THE AXIS OF MODERATE RAINFALL...TO POSSIBLY HEAVY RAINFALL...HAS 
SHIFTED TO THE NORTHERN PLATEAU SE TO THE SE TN MOUNTAINS AND SW 
NORTH CAROLINA. RAINFALL AMOUNTS HAVE BEEN HEAVIEST OVER SE TN AND 
THE CUMBERLAND PLATEAU DUE TO THE LONG DURATION SE FLOW. THIS AXIS 
WILL GRADUALLY SHIFT EAST OVERNIGHT WITH COLDER SOMEWHAT DRIER AIR 
WORKING IN FROM THE WEST. AFTER A BRIEF BREAK IN PRECIPITATION THE 
ROTATION AROUND THE UPPER LOW WILL INCREASE PRECIPITATION FROM THE 
SW WITH SNOW MIXING IN WITH THE RAIN THEIR FIRST SPREADING INTO THE 
HIGHER MOUNTAINS TUESDAY. WITH GROUND TEMPERATURES WARM FROM TODAY I 
AM NOT EXPECTING ANY SIGNIFICANT ACCUMULATION VALLEYS BUT AN INCH OR 
SO IS POSSIBLE ON THE HIGHER PLATEAU AREAS AND A COUPLE INCHES IN 
THE HIGHER EASTERN MOUNTAINS BY LATE TUESDAY. LOWS TONIGHT WILL 
STILL BE ABOVE FREEZING BUT HIGHS TOMORROW WILL NOT RISE MUCH AS THE 
COLDER AIR ALOFT MOVES IN WITH UPPER LOW. HIGHS TUESDAY SHOULD STAY 
IN THE 30S MOUNTAINS TO LOWER TO MID 40S ELSEWHERE WITH TEMPERATURES 
DROPPING DURING THE DAY MOST LOCATIONS.

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY)...COLDER AIR IS EXPECTED 
TO MOVE INTO THE FORECAST AREA TUESDAY NIGHT...AS THE SLOW-MOVING 
LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM GRADUALLY MOVES NORTHEAST ACROSS THE CENTRAL AND 
NORTHERN APPALACHIANS. MODELS STILL INDICATE SOME LINGERING MOISTURE 
OVER THE FORECAST AREA TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY MORNING...WHICH 
SHOULD TRANSITION OVER TO SNOW BEFORE ENDING. WITH A WET AND WARM 
GROUND IN THE LOWER ELEVATIONS...DO NOT ANTICIPATE ANY SNOW 
ACCUMULATIONS. HOWEVER...SOME LIGHT SNOW ACCUMULATIONS WILL BE 
POSSIBLE ACROSS THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS...GENERALLY ABOVE 2500 FEET. A 
COLD FRONT IS THEN PROGGED TO MOVE THROUGH THE FORECAST AREA ON 
FRIDAY...BUT THE GFS AND ECMWF MODELS AGREE THAT LIMITED MOISTURE 
SHOULD PREVENT ANY PRECIP. THE NEXT CHANCE FOR RAIN APPEARS TO BE 
WITH THE NEXT COLD FRONT FOR MONDAY...WITH A GOOD FETCH OF MOISTURE 
FROM THE SOUTHERN JET STREAM POSSIBLY PRODUCING ANOTHER VERY WET 
SCENARIO. AS FOR TEMPS...WILL GENERALLY TREND TOWARDS THE GFS 
GUIDANCE NUMBERS THROUGH SUNDAY...BUT WILL THEN TREND WARMER FOR 
SUNDAY NIGHT INTO MONDAY WHICH IS IN AGREEMENT WITH THE ECMWF MODEL 
SOLUTION.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1056 AM EST MON NOV 28 2011

.DISCUSSION...SLOW MOVING UPPER LOW NOW LOCATED ACROSS NE MS WITH
SURFACE LOW OVER CHA. AXIS OF MODERATE TO HEAVY RAINFALL STILL OVER
SOUTHEAST TN AND NOW UPSLOPE COMPONENT IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA IS
INCREASING RAINFALL THERE. RAINFALL AMOUNTS FOR THE 24 HOUR PERIOD ENDING
THIS MORNING AT 12Z WERE AS HIGH AS 4 TO ALMOST 5 INCHES ACROSS THE
SOUTHERN VALLEY AND SOUTHERN PLATEAU. THE AREAL AVERAGE FORECAST
FOR THE NEXT 24 HOURS IS FROM 1 TO 2 INCHES ACROSS EAST TN...SW NC
AND SW VA WITH HIGHER AMOUNTS POSSIBLE IN SOME AREAS. WILL CONTINUE
FLOOD WATCH. 850 MB WINDS AROUND 50 KNOTS WILL MOVE FROM SOUTHEAST
TN NORTH INTO SW VA THROUGH TODAY AND THIS EVENING SO WILL CONTINUE
WIND ADVISORY AS IS. TEMPERATURES RANGE FROM THE MID 40S PLATEAU TO
THE MID 60S NE. HAVE ADJUSTED TEMPERATURES AND DEW POINTS AND HAVE
TEMPERATURES STEADY OR FALLING SW SECTIONS FOR THE REST OF THE DAY
AND THEN OVER THE NE HALF DURING THE AFTERNOON AS THE SURFACE LOW
MOVES NORTH INTO KY. UPDATE ALREADY SENT.

542 
FXUS64 KMRX 280951
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
445 AM EST MON NOV 28 2011

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...SLOW MOVING UPPER LOW WILL TRACK 
INTO OUR AREA DURING THE SHORT TERM...AS SURFACE LOW AND SURFACE 
BOUNDARY FINALLY SHIFTS TO OUR NORTH.  RAIN WILL CONTINUE TODAY 
BEFORE TAPERING OFF SOUTHWEST TO NORTHEAST TONIGHT.  WILL LEAVE 
FLOOD WATCH AS IS FOR NOW...BUT THINK IT MAY BE ABLE TO END A BIT 
EARLIER THAN ITS CURRENT EXPIRATION.  DOES NOT LOOK LIKE A GOOD SET 
UP FOR MOUNTAIN WAVES...BUT STRONG LOW LEVEL JET CERTAINLY SHOULD 
BRING SOME GUSTY WINDS TO SOME OF THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS. PLAN TO 
TWEAK WIND ADVISORY AREAS AND TIMING...AND WILL CANCEL HIGH WIND 
WATCH.  COLDER AIR WILL MOVE IN TONIGHT...BUT LOOKS LIKE PRECIP WILL 
BE MOSTLY GONE BY THE TIME IT GETS COLD ENOUGH FOR ANY SNOW. WILL 
MENTION POSSIBILITY OF SNOW OVER SOME OF THE HIGHER TERRAIN...BUT 
NOT MUCH IN THE WAY OF ANY ACCUMULATION EXPECTED THROUGH LATE 
TONIGHT.    

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...MOST OF THE RAIN COMPLIMENTS 
OF THE PLUME OF DEEP MOISTURE WILL HAVE EXITED NORTHEAST OUT OF THE 
FORECAST AREA BY 12Z TUESDAY HOWEVER THE BACK EDGE OF THE STRONGER 
LIFT IN THE VICINITY OF THE SURFACE OCCLUDED FRONT MAY STILL BE 
ACROSS A SMALL PART OF SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA SHORTLY AFTER 12Z. THE 
NEXT FEATURE TO AFFECT THE REGION WILL BE THE DEEP UPPER LOW WHICH 
WILL BE MOVING DIRECTLY OVER THE TENNESSEE VALLEY/SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIANS ON TUESDAY ON ITS WAY TOWARD THE EASTERN GREAT LAKES BY 
12Z WEDNESDAY. MODEL FORECASTS HAVE BEEN FAIRLY CONSISTENT SHOWING 
AN AREA OF DEEP MOISTURE/LIFT BUILDING BACK INTO THE AREA ON TUESDAY 
IN ASSOCIATION WITH A VORT MAX SWINGING FROM THE TENNESSEE VALLEY OF 
ALABAMA EARLY IN THE DAY THROUGH SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA BY EARLY 
EVENING. VERY COLD AIR ALOFT UNDER THE UPPER LEVEL LOW SHOULD ALLOW 
FOR RAIN TO CHANGE TO SNOW IN THE HIGHER TERRAIN ABOVE 3000 FEET 
DURING THE DAY WITH A RAIN/SNOW MIX ACROSS PARTS OF THE CUMBERLAND 
PLATEAU AS COLD AIR ADVECTION STRENGTHENS FROM THE WEST. 
TEMPERATURES SHOULD BE COLD ENOUGH ABOVE 3000 FEET ELEVATION FOR 
SOME LIGHT SNOW ACCUMULATION ON TUESDAY TOTALING AROUND ONE INCH. BY 
TUESDAY NIGHT...TEMPERATURES SHOULD BE COLD ENOUGH FOR SOME SNOW TO 
MIX WITH THE RAIN IN THE GREAT VALLEY. LIGHT SNOW WILL CONTINUE IN 
THE MOUNTAINS TUESDAY NIGHT WITH ADDITIONAL AMOUNTS AROUND ONE HALF 
TO ONE INCH POSSIBLE AT ELEVATIONS ABOVE 2000 FEET. BY WEDNESDAY THE 
DEEPER MOISTURE AND LIFT ASSOCIATED WITH THE STRONG UPPER LEVEL 
SYSTEM WILL BE MOVING STEADILY NORTHEAST AWAY FROM THE FORECAST AREA 
HOWEVER...THERE WILL BE A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR A LIGHT SNOW/RAIN MIX IN 
THE VALLEY WITH LIGHT MOUNTAIN SNOWFALL THROUGH MID DAY. WAS ABLE TO 
STAY WITH THE DRY FORECAST THROUGH MUCH OF THE REMAINING LONG TERM 
PERIOD. KEPT THE SLIGHT CHANCE POP FOR SHOWERS SUNDAY NIGHT AS 
ANOTHER FRONTAL SYSTEM APPROACHES THROUGH THE MISSISSIPPI VALLEY. 
TRENDED TEMPERATURES TOWARD MEX MOS NUMBERS.

073 
FXUS64 KMRX 280215
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
915 PM EST SUN NOV 27 2011

.DISCUSSION...RADAR INDICATING THE MAJORITY OF THE ECHOES ACROSS THE 
WESTERN PORTIONS OF THE CWA AS THE FRONT TRACKS SLOWLY THROUGH THE 
AREA. WILL LEAVE CURRENT POPS AS IS. TEMPERATURES AND THE REST OF 
THE FORECAST ON TRACK. WILL UPDATE ZONES TO REMOVE EVENING WORDING. 
NO OTHER CHANGES PLANNED. 

.PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT)...VERY DYNAMIC SYSTEM 
WILL MOVE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA THROUGH THE SHORT-TERM. MODELS 
SHOW GOOD JET INTERACTION OVER THE TENNESSEE VALLEY PRODUCING STRONG 
AGEOSTROPHIC VERTICAL CIRCULATION ENHANCING FRONTOGENESIS FORCING 
ALONG A SLOW MOVING FRONTAL BOUNDARY. THIS BOUNDARY WILL REMAIN 
ACROSS THE AREA FOR TONIGHT AND MONDAY BEFORE EXITING MONDAY NIGHT. 
A BAND OF LIGHT TO MODERATE RAIN...OCCASIONAL HEAVY...WILL TRAIN 
NORTH ACROSS THE PLATEAU...SOUTHEAST TENNESSEE...AND SOUTHWEST NORTH 
CAROLINA PRODUCING RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 5 INCHES. LOCALLY HEAVY 
POSSIBLE. HAVE CONTINUED THE FLOOD WATCH UNTIL 4 AM TUESDAY MORNING 
AS RUN OFF WILL CONTINUE THROUGH TUESDAY.

STRONG DOWNSLOPING WINDS DUE TO A STRONG SOUTH TO SOUTHEAST LOW-
LEVEL JET OF 40-60KTS. THE DOWNSLOPE WINDS WILL LIMIT THE RAINFALL
FOR THE NORTHERN HALF OF THE TENNESSEE VALLEY. ALSO...THE LOW LEVEL
JET WILL CONTINUE TO PRODUCE WINDY CONDITIONS ACROSS THE MOUNTAINS
AND FOOTHILLS. A DAMAGING MOUNTAIN WAVE EVENT WITH POSSIBLE FOR THE
NORTH AND CENTRAL MOUNTAINS MONDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING. HAVE
ISSUED AN ADVISORY AREA-WIDE THROUGH MONDAY/MONDAY NIGHT AND A HIGH
WIND WATCH FOR THE NORTH AND CENTRAL MOUNTAINS TOMORROW.

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...
SHORT RANGE MODEL CONSENSUS PUTS THE UPPER LOW BY TUESDAY MORNING 
OVER SOUTHERN MIDDLE TN. RAINFALL WILL STILL BE OCCURRING OVER NE TN 
AND SW VA. THERE SHOULD BE A DRY SLOT MOVING ACROSS THE FORECAST 
AREA FOR AT LEAST A FEW HOURS TUESDAY AHEAD OF THE UPPER LOW 
CIRCULATION. PRECIPITATION SHOULD FILL BACK IN BY LATE IN THE DAY 
FROM SW TO NE AS UPPER LOW MOVES NE INTO KY. FREEZING LEVELS WILL 
DROP TO AROUND 2000 FEET SOUTH AND 4000 FEET NORTH BY TUESDAY 
MORNING AND THEN NEAR THE SURFACE BY TUESDAY NIGHT. SNOW WILL OCCUR 
AT THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS TUESDAY AND MAY MIX IN WITH SNOW LOWER 
ELEVATIONS AS TEMPERATURES HOLD STEADY IN THE LOWER TO MID 40S LOWER 
ELEVATIONS AND 30S HIGHER ELEVATIONS. SNOWFALL AMOUNTS LOOK TO BE 
LIGHT IN THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS WITH AN INCH OR TWO TUESDAY AND THEN 
AS THE MOISTURE AND LIFT DECREASES TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY ONLY 
ANOTHER INCH OR SO BEFORE THE SNOW ENDS DURING THE DAY WEDNESDAY. IN 
THE VALLEYS SNOWFALL THE SNOW WILL LIKELY MELT QUICKLY BUT OVER 
NORTHEAST SECTIONS AMOUNTS SHOULD BE LESS THAN ONE INCH TUESDAY 
NIGHT AND EARLY WEDNESDAY. PRECIPITATION WILL END FROM SW TO NE 
TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY AS THE UPPER LOW MOVES FROM EASTERN KY 
TO THE NE STATES WEDNESDAY NIGHT. LOWS IN THE VALLEY TUESDAY NIGHT 
SHOULD STAY JUST ABOVE FREEZING. WEDNESDAY HIGHS IN THE HIGHER 
ELEVATIONS AND NORTHEAST...INCLUDING PLATEAU MID 30S TO LOWER 40S 
AND MID TO UPPER 40S CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN LOW ELEVATION VALLEYS 
WHERE PRECIPITATION WILL BE ENDING. COOL HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD IN 
THURSDAY AND CONTINUE THROUGH THE WEEKEND. A WEAK SHORTWAVE WITH 
LIMITED MOISTURE MAY BRING IN SOME CLOUDINESS FRIDAY AND FRIDAY 
NIGHT BUT RIGHT NOW TOO DRY FOR ANY PRECIPITATION. TEMPERATURES 
SHOULD STAY COOLER THAN NORMAL IN THE MID 40S TO LOWER 50S FOR HIGHS 
AND MID 20S TO LOWER 30S FOR LOWS THURSDAY THROUGH SUNDAY           




&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             48  52  39  44  35 / 100 100  70  50  20 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  52  61  40  42  33 /  90  80 100  50  40 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       49  58  40  45  33 / 100 100 100  50  40 
TRI CITIES AIRPORT, TN              50  66  45  46  32 /  40  50  90  70  50 

&&

FXUS64 KMRX 271724
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1224 PM EST SUN NOV 27 2011

.AVIATION...A STRONG UPPER LEVEL STORM SYSTEM AND ASSOCIATED COLD 
FRONT WILL MOVE INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY THROUGH THE FORECAST 
PERIOD PRODUCING WIDESPREAD RAIN...SOME HEAVY...FROM TYS WESTWARD. 
DOWNSLOPING WINDS INTO THE NORTHERN HALF OF THE VALLEY WILL HELP 
KEEP RAIN SCATTERED AND CEILINGS HIGHER AT TRI. TIGHT PRESSURE 
GRADIENTS AROUND THIS SYSTEM WILL PRODUCE STRONG BOUNDARY LAYER JET 
WITH 850MB WINDS OF NEARLY 50KTS+. CIGS AND VIS WILL LOWER FROM 
SOUTHWEST TO NORTHEAST. WILL TAKE CHA AS LOW AS IFR LATE. WILL TAKE 
TYS TO MVFR TONIGHT AND TRI TO MVFR LATE. LOWER CONDITIONS ARE 
CERTAINLY POSSIBLE. LOW LEVEL JET FAIRLY STRONG...BUT LOOKS 
BORDERLINE FOR LOW LEVEL WIND SHEAR GIVEN EXPECTED SURFACE 
WINDS...SO NO MENTION IN TAFS FOR NOW.

&&

.MRX WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
NC...FLOOD WATCH FROM 5 PM EST THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH MONDAY EVENING 
     FOR THE FOLLOWING ZONES: CHEROKEE...CLAY.

TN...FLOOD WATCH FROM 5 PM EST /4 PM CST/ THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH 
     MONDAY EVENING FOR THE FOLLOWING ZONES: ANDERSON...
     BLEDSOE...BLOUNT SMOKY MOUNTAINS...BRADLEY...CAMPBELL...
     COCKE SMOKY MOUNTAINS...EAST POLK...HAMILTON...JEFFERSON...
     KNOX...LOUDON...MARION...MCMINN...MEIGS...MORGAN...NW 
     BLOUNT...NORTH SEVIER...NORTHWEST COCKE...NORTHWEST 
     MONROE...RHEA...ROANE...SCOTT TN...SEQUATCHIE...SEVIER 
     SMOKY MOUNTAINS...SOUTHEAST MONROE...WEST POLK.

     WIND ADVISORY UNTIL 7 PM EST THIS EVENING FOR THE FOLLOWING 
     ZONES: BLOUNT SMOKY MOUNTAINS...COCKE SMOKY MOUNTAINS...
     MCMINN...NW BLOUNT...NORTH SEVIER...NORTHWEST COCKE...

FXUS64 KMRX 271436 AAA
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
936 AM EST SUN NOV 27 2011

.DISCUSSION...AREA REPORTS ARE DEPICTING WIND ADVISORY CRITERIA
WINDS ACROSS THE CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN MOUNTAINS AND FOOTHILLS.
MODELS SHOW CONTINUED TIGHT PRESSURE GRADIENTS THROUGH THE DAY AND
INTO TONIGHT AND MONDAY. HAVE ISSUED A WINDY ADVISORY FOR
TODAY...BUT WILL LIKELY HAVE TO EXTEND IT THROUGH MONDAY. IN
ADDITION...BACKING WINDS TO MORE OF A SOUTHEAST COMPONENT FOR
MONDAY AND INCREASED WINDS MAY WARRANT A HIGH WIND WATCH FOR THE
MOUNTAINS AND FOOTHILLS TOMORROW.

DOWNSLOPE WINDS INTO THE NORTHERN AND CENTRAL VALLEY HAVE ALLOWED
TEMPERATURES TO WARM TO NEAR FORECASTED HIGHS...SO HAVE RAISED MAX
FOR TODAY.

CURRENT FLOOD WATCH CONFIGURATION LOOKS GOOD.

724 
FXUS64 KMRX 270940
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
430 AM EST SUN NOV 27 2011

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...SLOW MOVING UPPER TROUGH WILL 
APPROACH...WITH FRONTAL BOUNDARY SLOWLY MOVING IN TONIGHT.  STRONG 
SOUTHERLY WINDS WILL FEED CONSIDERABLE MOISTURE INTO THE AREA...AND 
WITH THE EXTENDED PERIOD OF RAIN THERE IS A POTENTIAL FOR SOME 
FAIRLY HEAVY RAINFALL AMOUNTS.  WILL ISSUE A FLOOD WATCH FOR ALL BUT 
NORTHEAST COUNTIES FOR LATE TODAY AND TONIGHT...AND THIS WILL EXTEND 
INTO MONDAY.  WINDS ARE ANOTHER CONCERN...AS LOW LEVEL JET WILL BE 
STRONG.  SOME CONCERN FOR MOUNTAIN WAVES...ALTHOUGH WIND DIRECTION 
MAY STAY JUST A BIT TOO SOUTHWEST.  FOR NOW GIVEN UNCERTAINTY WILL 
NOT ISSUE ANY WIND ADVISORIES/WARNINGS...BUT THIS WILL NEED TO BE 
MONITORED.  WILL NOT STRAY FAR FROM MAV TEMPS.   

.LONG TERM (MONDAY THROUGH SATURDAY)...MODELS RELATIVELY CLOSE IN 
DEPICTION OF DEEPENING UPPER LOW MAKING THE JOURNEY FROM THE LOWER 
MISSISSIPPI VALLEY NORTHEAST TO MIDDLE TENNESSEE 12Z MONDAY THROUGH 
12Z TUESDAY. DURING THE SAME PERIOD SURFACE LOW PRESSURE WILL SHIFT 
NORTH FROM NORTHWEST GEORGIA INTO THE OHIO VALLEY. PLUME OF DEEP 
MOISTURE WILL ACCOMPANY THE SYSTEM DURING ITS TREK GENERATING 
WIDESPREAD MODERATE TO OCCASIONALLY HEAVY RAIN ACROSS MUCH OF 
SOUTHEAST AND EAST CENTRAL TENNESSEE AS WELL AS SOUTHWEST NORTH 
CAROLINA WHERE THE FLOOD WATCH CONTINUES UNTIL 00Z TUESDAY. AS DRIER 
AIR WRAPS AROUND THE STORM CIRCULATION...PRECIPITATION SHOULD 
GRADUALLY TAPER OFF FROM SOUTHWEST THROUGH NORTHEAST MONDAY NIGHT. 
POCKET OF COLD AIR ALOFT ASSOCIATED WITH THE UPPER LEVEL LOW SHOULD 
ALLOW FOR THE RAIN TO MIX WITH SNOW AT ELEVATIONS ABOVE 3500 FEET 
MONDAY NIGHT. RAINFALL SHOULD CONTINUE TO DECREASE IN COVERAGE 
ACROSS MOST OF THE FORECAST AREA ON TUESDAY AS THE UPPER LOW SHIFTS 
SLOWLY NORTHEAST TOWARD THE UPPER OHIO VALLEY. AGAIN...TEMPERATURES 
ALOFT WILL SUPPORT SNOWFALL IN THE MOUNTAINS ON TUESDAY AS THE UPPER 
LOW MOVES SLOWLY NORTHEAST AND SNOW MAY BECOME MIXED WITH THE RAIN 
EVEN IN THE LOWER ELEVATIONS AS COLD AIR ADVECTION STRENGTHENS FROM 
THE WEST. BY TUESDAY NIGHT THE UPPER LOW WILL HAVE SHIFTED WELL 
NORTHEAST OF THE AREA BUT MODELS AGREE A TRAILING SHORTWAVE WILL 
MOVE ACROSS THE MID SOUTH KEEPING A CHANCE FOR PRECIPITATION GOING 
TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY AND LOW LEVEL THICKNESS WILL CONTINUE 
TO SUPPORT A MIXTURE OF RAIN AND SNOW...WITH SNOW BEING THE MAIN 
PRECIP TYPE IN THE HIGHER TERRAIN. BY WEDNESDAY NIGHT THE ENTIRE 
FORECAST AREA SHOULD BE DRY AND THIS TREND MAY CONTINUE THROUGH 
SATURDAY AS THE MODELS TRY TO BRING ANOTHER UPPER TROUGH ACROSS THE 
APPALACHIANS ON FRIDAY BUT MOISTURE WILL BE QUITE LIMITED. TRENDED 
THE TEMPERATURE FORECAST TOWARD THE NEW MEX MOS GUIDANCE ESPECIALLY 
LATER IN THE PERIOD.

&&

FXUS64 KMRX 262020
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
320 PM EST SAT NOV 26 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND SUNDAY)...HIGH PRESSURE EXITING THE REGION 
THIS EVENING AS A STRONG LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM APPROACHES THE AREA.  
CLOUDS WILL INCREASE OVERNIGHT WITH RAIN EXPECTED TO REACH INTO AT 
LEAST FAR WESTERN LOCATIONS BY SUNRISE.  RAIN WILL SPREAD INTO THE 
MRX CWA ON SUNDAY AND WINDS WILL INCREASE AND BECOME BREEZY AS THE 
FRONT APPRAOCHES.  

.LONG TERM (SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY)...AMPLIFIED UPPER TROUGH 
TO MOVE INTO THE EASTERN STATES BY SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY WITH 
HEAVY RAINFALL POTENTIAL ACROSS THE SOUTHWEST PART OF THE FORECAST 
AREA SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY. THE COLD FRONT WILL SLOW DOWN AS A 
CLOSED UPPER LOW FORMS OVER THE LOWER MS VALLEY. AT THE SURFACE 
AHEAD OF THE UPPER LOW A LOWER PRESSURE WILL DEEPEN AND ENHANCE 
RAINFALL ESPECIALLY OVER THE SE TN AND SW NC MOUNTAINS. 48 HOUR 
RAINFALL AMOUNTS OF 3 TO 5 INCHES ARE POSSIBLE BY MONDAY EVENING IN 
THE MOUNTAINS WITH SLIGHTLY LOWER AMOUNTS PLATEAU AND VALLEY AREAS. 
HAVE ISSUED HYDROLOGIC OUTLOOK TO ADDRESS THE POSSIBILITY OF 
FLOODING. TEMPERATURES WILL BE MILD SUNDAY NIGHT INTO  MONDAY WITH 
STRONG SOUTH TO SOUTHEAST WINDS AS LOW PRESSURE MOVES NORTH ACROSS 
THE MOUNTAINS TOWARD THE OHIO VALLEY. WINDS WILL SHIFT TO THE N OR 
NW MONDAY OR MONDAY NIGHT DEPENDING ON THE SPEED OF THE SYSTEM AND 
TEMPERATURES WILL DROP INTO THE UPPER 30S TO LOWER 40S BY TUESDAY 
MORNING. COLD AIR ADVECTION ON THE BACK SIDE OF THE UPPER LOW WILL 
BRING THE RISK OF SNOW TO THE REGION EARLY TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY. 
SOME LIGHT ACCUMULATIONS ARE POSSIBLE MAINLY TUESDAY NIGHT AND 
WEDNESDAY AS COLDER AIR MOVES IN. SNOW COULD STICK EVEN IN THE 
VALLEY AREAS BU THE TRACK OF THE LOW AND THE SPEED IT MOVES NORTH OR 
NORTHEAST IS STILL UNCERTAIN WHICH WILL AFFECT SNOWFALL AMOUNTS. 
HIGHER PRESSURE BUILDS BACK IN WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY WITH 
SKIES CLEARING. TEMPERATURES WILL STAY COOL WITH HIGHS IN THE 40S TO 
LOWER 50S AND LOWS IN THE 20S AND 30S.

957 
FXUS64 KMRX 260939
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
439 AM EST SAT NOV 26 2011

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...HIGH PRESSURE OVER REGION BRINGING 
ANOTHER DRY DAY TODAY. BUT A FRONT AND AREA OF LOW PRESSURE 
APPROACHING FROM THE WEST TONIGHT. WILL KEEP THE HIGHEST CHANCES FOR 
TONIGHT AND FOR OUR WESTERN ZONES. SHOULD BE WARM ENOUGH FOR ALL 
LIQUID PRECIPITATION. CLOUDS SHOULD MINIMIZE ANY FOG THAT DEVELOPS 
THIS MORNING SO WILL NOT MENTION IN THE FORECAST.  TEMPERATURES 
SHOULD STAY ABOVE NORMAL FOR TODAY AND TONIGHT. GUIDANCE 
TEMPERATURES LOOKED REASONABLE SO STAYED CLOSE. 

.LONG TERM (SUNDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...ECMWF PROVED TO BE THE BEST 
MODEL FOR USE DURING THE EXTENDED FORECAST FEATURING AN AMPLIFIED 
UPPER LEVEL TROUGH IN PLACE OVER THE MIDDLE OF THE NATION ON 12Z 
SUNDAY. ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT WILL BE A SLOWER MOVER AS AN UPPER 
LEVEL LOW FORMS ACROSS THE MID MISSISSIPPI VALLEY LATER IN THE DAY 
AND SHIFTS SLOWLY SOUTHEAST TOWARD THE TENNESSEE VALLEY OF ALABAMA 
BY 12Z MONDAY. THEREFORE...CATEGORICAL OR LIKELY POPS WERE APPLIED 
FOR SHOWERS OVER MOST OF THE FORECAST AREA ON SUNDAY WITH THE 
EXCEPTION OF NORTHEAST TENNESSEE WHERE STRONG DOWNSLOPING MAY KEEP 
RAIN OUT OF THE PICTURE UNTIL SUNDAY NIGHT. A STRONG LOW LEVEL JET 
WILL DEVELOP ACROSS THE REGION SUNDAY NIGHT INTO MONDAY AND MOUNTAIN 
WAVE CONDITIONS WILL IMPACT THE HIGHER TERRAIN DURING THIS PERIOD. 
STAYED WITH THE RATHER HIGH PROBABILITY OF RAIN THROUGH MONDAY FOR 
MOST OF THE REGION AS DEEPENING UPPER LOW/SURFACE LOW PRESSURE 
SYSTEM LUMBER ONLY SLOWLY EAST. THE UPPER FEATURE WILL BE 
ACCOMPANIED BY VERY COLD AIR ALOFT AND SOME OF THE HIGHER TERRAIN 
MAY SEE SOME SNOW MIX WITH THE RAIN...ESPECIALLY ACROSS THE SMOKY 
MOUNTAINS AS IT TRACKS NORTHEAST ACROSS THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS. 
THE STRONG CIRCULATION AROUND THE STORM SYSTEM WILL RESULT IN A 
HEALTHY DOSE OF COLD AIR ADVECTION TUESDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY AND 
LIGHT RAIN MAY CHANGE TO LIGHT SNOW ACROSS MOST OF THE FORECAST AREA 
WITH EMPHASIS IN THE HIGHER TERRAIN. SOME SNOW MAY CONTINUE ACROSS 
SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA AND THE MOUNTAINS ALONG THE NORTH CAROLINA BORDER 
THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON BEFORE ENDING. DRY ADVECTION AND RISING 
HEIGHTS SHOULD FINISH OUT THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD ALLOWING A 
RETURN TO DRY WEATHER THROUGH THE REMAINDER OF THE WORK WEEK. 
FABRICATED THE TEMP FORECAST THROUGH THE PERIOD TO MORE CLOSELY 
MATCH THE ECMWF SCENARIO SO DID NOT REALLY USE THE MEX MOS 
NUMBERS.

711 
FXUS64 KMRX 252007
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
307 PM EST FRI NOV 25 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND SATURDAY)...ANOTHER SHORT TERM WITH HIGH 
PRESSURE IN CONTROL. THIS WILL CONTINUE THE WEATHER REGIME OF MAINLY 
CLEAR SKIES...LIGHT WINDS AND SEASONALLY WARM DAYS AND COOL NIGHTS.  
WITH AN APPROACHING WEATHER SYSTEM LATER IN THE WEEKEND...COULD SEE 
CLOUDS BEGIN TO INCREASE LATE IN THE PERIOD.

.LONG TERM (SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY)...NEXT SYSTEM WILL BEGIN 
TO AFFECT THE FORECAST AREA SATURDAY NIGHT WITH SKIES BECOMING 
CLOUDY AND RAIN BEGINNING. A GOOD SOUTHERLY FLOW WILL KEEP 
TEMPERATURES SEVERAL DEGREES WARMER THAN INITIALLY FORECAST MID 40S 
TO MID 50S. THE COLD FRONT WILL MOVE THROUGH DURING THE DAY SUNDAY 
WITH WIDESPREAD SHOWERS AND STILL MILD TEMPERATURES AHEAD OF THE 
FRONT. MODEL FORECASTS STILL NOT ALL IN LINE FOR THE PROGRESSION 
AFTER THE INITIAL COLD FRONT. NAM AND GFS ARE FASTER WITH SYSTEM 
DEVELOPING AN UPPER LOW BEHIND COLD FRONT SUNDAY NIGHT OVER THE OHIO 
OR TN VALLEYS AND MOVING IT THROUGH THE FORECAST AREA MONDAY INTO 
TUESDAY. CANADIAN/ECMWF HOWEVER DEVELOP UPPER LOW OVER THE LOWER MS 
VALLEY AND TRAP IT AWAY FROM THE WESTERLIES SO IT SPINS FOR ANOTHER 
DAY OR SO. THIS KEEPS IT CLOUDY AND WET AND WARMER ANOTHER DAY 
BEFORE THE COLD AIR STARTS BEING PULLED INTO THE FORECAST AREA. FOR 
FORECAST WITH CONFIDENCE STILL LACKING HAVE BLENDED MODELS TO GO 
MORE WITH A GFS/ECMWF BLEND. KEPT LOWS ABOVE FREEZING SUNDAY NIGHT 
AND MONDAY NIGHT WITH ONLY MINOR SNOWFALL EXPECTED. HIGHS MONDAY 
MUCH COOLER BEHIND FRONT...A LITTLE WARMER TUESDAY. THEN TUESDAY 
NIGHT WITH LOWS NEAR FREEZING OR BELOW THERE COULD BE SOME 
ACCUMULATING SNOW ESPECIALLY IN THE MOUNTAINS. STILL HAVE POPS NE 
WEDNESDAY. HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN LATER WEDNESDAY WITH SKIES MOSTLY 
CLEAR FOR THE LAST TWO DAYS OF THE WEEK.  

&&

.LONG TERM (SATURDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...MODEL FORECASTS COVERING 
THIS PERIOD ARE ALL OVER THE PLACE AND THUS CONFIDENCE IS LOW. TRIED 
TO STAY CLOSER TO A CANADIAN/GFS BLEND EARLY FOLLOWED BY A 
CANADIAN/ECMWF BLEND FROM MONDAY FORWARD. UPPER TROUGH AND 
ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT BRING SOME SHOWERS TO THE FORECAST AREA 
SATURDAY NIGHT INTO SUNDAY WITH THE SYSTEM SLOWING DOWN AS SOUTHERN 
STREAM ENERGY AIDS INTENSIFICATION OF THE TROUGH OVER THE 
SOUTHEASTERN U.S. A TRAILING UPPER LEVEL LOW MAKES SLOW PROGRESS 
ACROSS THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY KEEPING A 
CHANCE FOR SHOWERS (AND POSSIBLY A FEW LIGHT SNOW SHOWERS FOR 
NORTHERN SECTIONS AND HIGHER TERRAIN) GOING INTO TUESDAY NIGHT 
BEFORE ENDING. AS THE UPPER TROUGH LIFTS OUT DRY ADVECTION BEGINS 
ALLOWING FOR A RETURN TO SUNSHINE ON WEDNESDAY WHILE THE FORECAST 
AREA AWAITS THE ARRIVAL OF A LATE WORK WEEK SYSTEM THAT MAY BRING A 
FEW MORE SHOWERS TO THE REGION THURSDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING. WAS 
NOT ABLE TO USE MEX MOS TEMPERATURE GUIDANCE DUE TO THE MAJOR LEAGUE 
DIFFERENCES NOTED IN THE LONG TERM MODELS.

FXUS64 KMRX 250922
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
415 AM EST FRI NOV 25 2011

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...RIDGING ACROSS THE REGION 
PROVIDING DRY WEATHER FOR TODAY AND TONIGHT. WITH LINGERING LOW 
LEVEL MOISTURE ALONG WITH A CLEAR SKY AND LIGHT WIND...MAY SEE 
PATCHY FOG DEVELOPING DURING THE MORNING HOURS. BUT DENSE FOG 
LOCATIONS WILL BE ISOLATED SO WILL NOT ISSUE AN ADVISORY. 
TEMPERATURES SHOULD RETURN TO ABOVE NORMAL FOR TODAY AND TONIGHT. 
GUIDANCE TEMPERATURES LOOKED REASONABLE SO STAYED CLOSE.   

.LONG TERM (SATURDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...MODEL FORECASTS COVERING 
THIS PERIOD ARE ALL OVER THE PLACE AND THUS CONFIDENCE IS LOW. TRIED 
TO STAY CLOSER TO A CANADIAN/GFS BLEND EARLY FOLLOWED BY A 
CANADIAN/ECMWF BLEND FROM MONDAY FORWARD. UPPER TROUGH AND 
ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT BRING SOME SHOWERS TO THE FORECAST AREA 
SATURDAY NIGHT INTO SUNDAY WITH THE SYSTEM SLOWING DOWN AS SOUTHERN 
STREAM ENERGY AIDS INTENSIFICATION OF THE TROUGH OVER THE 
SOUTHEASTERN U.S. A TRAILING UPPER LEVEL LOW MAKES SLOW PROGRESS 
ACROSS THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY KEEPING A 
CHANCE FOR SHOWERS (AND POSSIBLY A FEW SNOW SHOWERS FOR NORTHERN 
SECTIONS AND HIGHER TERRAIN) GOING INTO TUESDAY NIGHT BEFORE ENDING. 
AS THE UPPER TROUGH LIFTS OUT DRY ADVECTION BEGINS ALLOWING FOR A 
RETURN TO SUNSHINE ON WEDNESDAY WHILE THE FORECAST AREA AWAITS THE 
ARRIVAL OF A LATE WORK WEEK SYSTEM THAT MAY BRING A FEW MORE SHOWERS 
TO THE REGION THURSDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING. WAS NOT ABLE TO USE 
MEX MOS TEMPERATURE GUIDANCE DUE TO THE MAJOR LEAGUE DIFFERENCES 
NOTED IN THE LONG TERM MODELS.       

&&

FXUS64 KMRX 242015
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
315 PM EST THU NOV 24 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND FRIDAY)...QUIET WEATHER PATTERN THROUGH THE 
SHORT TERM WITH HIGH PRESSURE IN CONTROL.  THE RESULT WILL BE 
CONTINUED CLEAR SKIES AND LIGHT WINDS FOR A COOL NIGHT TONIGHT AND A 
WARM DAY ON FRIDAY.

.LONG TERM (FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY)...HIGH PRESSURE AT THE 
SURFACE AND ALOFT WILL CONTINUE ABOUT 24 MORE HOURS BEFORE THE NEXT 
PATTERN CHANGE. LOWS WILL BE SLIGHTLY WARMER AS SURFACE HIGH BEGINS 
TO SHIFT EAST AND SOUTH WINDS BEGIN NEAR CHA AND ALOFT. LOWS WILL BE 
GENERALLY LOWER 30S TO LOWER 40S. SATURDAY INCREASING MOISTURE BY 
LATE IN THE DAY AS COLD FRONT MOVES INTO MS VALLEY AND WESTERN TN 
VALLEY. HIGHS STILL MILD IN THE 60S AT THE LOWER ELEVATIONS. MODELS 
IN AGREEMENT SATURDAY NIGHT AND SUNDAY WITH INCREASED RAIN THREAT AS 
COLD FRONT APPROACHES. MUCH COOLER SATURDAY WITH CLOUDS...RAIN AND 
COLD AIR ADVECTION. HIGHS MOSTLY 40S TO LOWER 50S. MODELS DIVERGE 
SUNDAY NIGHT INTO WEDNESDAY WITH GFS MOVING SYSTEM THROUGH QUICKLY 
WITH WRAP AROUND PRECIPITATION AFFECTING THE REGION SUNDAY NIGHT AND 
MONDAY WHILE ECMWF AND CANADIAN DEVELOPING UPPER LOWS BEHIND SYSTEM 
MONDAY EITHER OVER AL OR LOWER MS VALLEY AND KEEPING PRECIPITATION 
OVER THE REGION THROUGH WEDNESDAY WITH NEAR TO BELOW FREEZING AT 
NIGHT WITH SNOW SHOWERS POSSIBLE. WILL HAVE A LITTLE SNOW IN SUNDAY 
NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT AND MAINLY RAIN DURING THE DAY. 
CONFIDENCE IS NOT THAT GREAT DUE TO THE DIFFERENCES. WEDNESDAY AND 
THURSDAY FOLLOWED THE DRIER GFS WITH HIGH PRESSURE AND MOSTLY CLEAR 
CONDITIONS.

978 
FXUS64 KMRX 240834
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
334 AM EST THU NOV 24 2011

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...HIGH PRESSURE ACROSS THE REGION 
PROVIDING DRY WEATHER TODAY AND TONIGHT. WITH THE RECENT RAIN AND 
CLEAR SKY AND LIGHT WIND...WILL PROBABLY SEE FOG DEVELOPING DURING 
THE MORNING HOURS. BUT DENSE FOG LOCATIONS WILL BE ISOLATED SO WILL 
NOT ISSUE AN ADVISORY. TEMPERATURES SHOULD BE BACK TO NEAR TO ABOVE 
NORMAL. GUIDANCE TEMPERATURES LOOKED REASONABLE SO STAYED 
RELATIVELY CLOSE. 

.LONG TERM (FRIDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...GFS AND ECMWF MODELS ARE 
REVEALING SOME LARGE DISCREPANCIES WITH THE SYNOPTIC PATTERN IN THE 
EXTENDED PERIOD BEGINNING SATURDAY NIGHT...WITH THE OTHER ENSEMBLE 
MEMBERS ALSO SHOWING LARGE DISCREPANCIES WITH THE PATTERN FOR EARLY 
NEXT WEEK. OVERALL...WILL PLAN TO TREND CLOSER TO THE ECMWF SOLUTION 
THROUGH THE EXTENDED...SINCE IT HAS MAINTAINED BETTER CONSISTENCY 
OVER THE PAST SEVERAL MODEL RUNS THAN THE GFS MODEL. A HIGHLY 
AMPLIFIED UPPER-LEVEL TROUGH IS PROGGED TO DEVELOP OVER THE PLAINS 
ON SATURDAY...WHICH WILL PUSH A COLD FRONT ACROSS THE TN RIVER 
VALLEY ON SATURDAY NIGHT AND SUNDAY. ECMWF MODEL CONTINUES TO BE 
AROUND 12 HOURS SLOWER THAN THE GFS MODEL WITH THE EASTWARD 
PROGRESSION OF THIS COLD FRONT...BUT WILL CONTINUE TO TREND TOWARDS 
A COMPROMISE SOLUTION BY MENTIONING A GOOD CHANCE OF SHOWERS FOR 
SATURDAY NIGHT. A GOOD FETCH OF MOISTURE FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO 
SHOULD HELP TO PRODUCE A FAIRLY WET SCENARIO FOR SUNDAY OVER THE 
FORECAST AREA. ECMWF MODEL CONTINUES TO SHOW THE HIGHLY AMPLIFIED 
UPPER-LEVEL TROUGH BECOMING A CUT-OFF LOW OVER THE DEEP SOUTH ON 
MONDAY...WHILE THE LATEST GFS MODEL RUN INDICATES THAT THIS UPPER 
TROUGH WILL NOT CUT OFF FROM THE NORTHERN STREAM. SINCE THE LATEST 
GFS SOLUTION IS THE FIRST MODEL TO SHOW THIS TYPE OF PATTERN...WILL 
IGNORE THE GFS MODEL BEYOND SUNDAY AND CONTINUE TO TREND TOWARDS THE 
ECMWF SOLUTION OF A WET PERIOD FOR MONDAY AND TUESDAY. THE ECMWF 
MODEL ALSO CONTINUES TO REVEAL A WARMER VERTICAL TEMP PROFILE OVER 
THE FORECAST AREA FOR EARLY NEXT WEEK...WHICH WOULD SUPPORT MOSTLY 
RAIN UNTIL TUESDAY NIGHT WHEN COLDER AIR BEHIND ANOTHER COLD FRONT 
BRINGS THE POSSIBILITY OF SOME SNOW SHOWERS OVER THE HIGHER 
ELEVATIONS. HOWEVER BY THEN...MOST OF THE MOISTURE WITH THIS UPPER 
LOW SHOULD BE MOVING NORTHEASTWARD OUT OF THE FORECAST AREA. AS FOR 
TEMPS...WILL TREND CLOSE TO THE GFS GUIDANCE NUMBERS THROUGH SUNDAY. 
FOR EARLY NEXT WEEK...WILL TREND WARMER THAN THE GFS NUMBERS...WHICH 
IS IN BETTER AGREEMENT WITH THE ECMWF SOLUTION AND THE ENSEMBLE 
MEANS.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  62  36  66  43  63 /   0   0   0   0  10

079 
FXUS64 KMRX 231940
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
240 PM EST WED NOV 23 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND THURSDAY)...
OVERCAST CLOUDS ARE BECOMING MORE BROKEN AS DRY AIR ALOFT WORKS IT 
WAY INTO THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION. EXPECT THAT THE CLOUDS 
WILL BECOME SCATTERED BY SUNSET...WITH CLEAR SKIES SOON AFTER. WITH 
THE EXPECTED CLEARING AND WINDS BECOMING CALM AS HIGH PRESSURE 
BUILDS IN...AREAS OF FOG APPEAR LIKELY TONIGHT. UPSTREAM DEWPOINTS 
ACROSS KY AND THE OHIO VALLEY ARE IN THE LOWER 40S...SO NO 
SIGNIFICANT SURFACE DRY AIR WILL ADVECT INTO THE AREA. 
SURPRISINGLY...MOS GUIDANCE SHOWS LITTLE TO NO FOG. WILL MENTION 
AREAS OF FOG IN THE FORECAST TONIGHT BUT LET THE EVENING RE-EVALUATE 
THE NEED FOR A DENSE FOG ADVISORY. GIVEN THE HIGH UPSTREAM DEWPOINTS 
AND THE LIKELY FORMATION OF FOG...LEANED TOWARD THE WARMER SIDE OF 
GUIDANCE FOR LOW TEMPERATURES TONIGHT. AFTER THE FOG BURNS OFF 
MID-MORNING...THANKSGIVING DAY WILL FEATURE PLENTY OF SUNSHINE AND 
HIGHS IN THE UPPER 50S TO MID 60S UNDER STRONG HIGH PRESSURE.

.LONG TERM (THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...
HIGH PRESSURE IN CONTROL EARLY IN THE PERIOD FOR SEASONALLY WARM
AND DRY CONDITIONS THROUGH SATURDAY. A COLD FRONT WILL MOVE IN
SATURDAY NIGHT INTO SUNDAY. MODELS CONTINUE TO SHOW DIFFERENCES IN
TIMING OF THE FRONTAL PASSAGE AND ASSOCIATED SHOWERS MOVING IN.
WILL CONTINUE TO COMPROMISE IN THE TIMING OF PRECIP FOR HIGH CHANCE
AND LIKE POPS SATURDAY NIGHT WITH LIKELY POPS ON SUNDAY. MODELS
CONTINUE TO DIVERGE WITH TIMING AND PLACEMENT OF AN UPPER LOW
MONDAY AND TUESDAY. THESE DIFFERENCES WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACT
TEMPERATURES...PRECIP CHANCES AND PRECIP TYPE AND CONFIDENCE IS
LOW. FOR NOW...WILL KEEP SCATTERED SHOWERS MONDAY...DECREASING TO
ISOLATED SHOWERS OVER MOST LOCATIONS ON TUESDAY. HIGHER ELEVATIONS
SHOULD EXPECTED SOME SNOWFALL...LOWER ELEVATIONS...ESPECIALLY
NORTHERN AREAS...COULD SEE A MIX OF RAIN AND SNOW LATE MONDAY NIGHT
INTO EARLY TUESDAY MORNING. KEPT THINGS DRY FOR WEDNESDAY.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

212 
FXUS64 KMRX 231456 AAA
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION...UPDATED
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
956 AM EST WED NOV 23 2011

.DISCUSSION...
THE UPPER TROUGH AXIS IS SWINGING THROUGH THE AREA THIS MORNING.
UPSTREAM SOUNDINGS INDICATE THAT DRIER AIR ALOFT WILL CONTINUE TO
ADVECT IN THROUGH THE AFTERNOON BEHIND THE TROUGH. 12Z OHX SOUNDING
SHOWS MOISTURE CONFINED BELOW 850 MB...AND MOISTURE DEPTH WILL ONLY
DECREASE THROUGH THE DAY. AS A RESULT...WILL REMOVE THE SLIGHT
CHANCE POP IN NORTHERN AREAS AND THE MOUNTAINS. CLOUDS WILL
EVENTUALLY THIN OUT AS BOTH THE RUC AND NAM SHOW CLEARING LATE IN
THE AFTERNOON...BUT EXPECT THIS TO OCCUR A BIT MORE SLOWLY THAN THE
MODELS SUGGEST. THUS WILL LOWER TEMPERATURES SLIGHTLY IN ALL
LOCATIONS. 

THE NEED FOR A WIND ADVISORY WAS CONSIDERED IN SW VA AND THE TN
MOUNTAINS...HOWEVER THERE HAVE BEEN NO OBSERVATIONS IN THE AREA
CLOSE TO ADVISORY CRITERIA...AND MODELS INDICATE DECREASING WINDS
THROUGH THE DAY AS THE SURFACE LOW MOVES FARTHER OFF THE NEW
ENGLAND COAST. NO WIND ADVISORY WILL BE NEEDED.

&&

.MRX WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
NC...NONE.

136 
FXUS64 KMRX 230842
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
342 AM EST WED NOV 23 2011

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...RADAR INDICATING THE FRONT AND 
UPPER TROUGH TRIGGERING A NARROW LINE OF LIGHT SHOWERS. MOST OF THE 
ACTIVITY SHOULD END TODAY AS THE TROUGH EXITS THE CWA. SO KEPT 
THE HIGHEST CHANCES FOR THE MORNING HOURS. ALSO EXPECTING DECREASING 
TODAY WITH TEMPERATURES BACK TO NEAR NORMAL. RIDGE BUILDING BACK 
INTO THE REGION PROVIDING A RETURN TO DRY WEATHER TONIGHT. GUIDANCE 
TEMPERATURES LOOKED REASONABLE SO DIDN'T STRAY TOO FAR. 

.LONG TERM (THURSDAY THROUGH TUESDAY)...MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT 
WITH THE OVERALL SYNOPTIC PATTERN THROUGH THE EXTENDED PERIOD...BUT 
SHOW SOME DISCREPANCIES WITH THE TIMING OF THE NEXT COLD FRONT OVER 
THE WEEKEND. A LARGE DOME OF HIGH PRESSURE WILL SETTLE OVER THE 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION ON THURSDAY...WITH UPPER-LEVEL RIDGING 
LINGERING OVER THE EASTERN HALF OF THE NATION INTO SATURDAY... 
RESULTING IN UNSEASONABLY MILD AND TRANQUIL CONDITIONS. A HIGHLY 
AMPLIFIED UPPER-LEVEL TROUGH IS PROGGED TO DEVELOP OVER THE PLAINS 
ON SATURDAY...WHICH WILL PUSH A COLD FRONT ACROSS THE TN RIVER 
VALLEY ON SATURDAY NIGHT INTO SUNDAY. ECMWF MODEL IS A LITTLE SLOWER 
THAN THE GFS MODEL WITH THE EASTWARD PROGRESSION OF THIS COLD 
FRONT...AND FOR NOW...WILL TREND TOWARDS A COMPROMISE SOLUTION WITH 
SHOWERS BEGINNING TO AFFECT THE FORECAST AREA ON SATURDAY NIGHT. A 
GOOD FETCH OF MOISTURE FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO SHOULD HELP TO 
PRODUCE A FAIRLY EXTENSIVE COVERAGE OF SHOWERS ON SUNDAY. THE HIGHLY 
AMPLIFIED UPPER-LEVEL TROUGH IS THEN PROGGED TO BECOME A CUT-OFF LOW 
OVER THE SOUTHEAST ON MONDAY...WHICH WILL CONTINUE TO PRODUCE 
SCATTERED SHOWERS OVER THE FORECAST AREA (ESPECIALLY THE NORTHERN 
HALF) ON MONDAY AND TUESDAY. THIS UPPER LOW WILL ALSO BRING COOLER 
TEMPS ALOFT...WHICH WILL COULD PRODUCE SOME SNOW SHOWERS OVER THE 
HIGHER ELEVATIONS DEPENDING ON WHICH MODEL SOLUTION VERIFIES. ECMWF 
MODEL KEEPS UPPER-LEVEL TEMPS WARM ENOUGH FOR MAINLY RAIN EARLY NEXT 
WEEK...WHILE THE GFS MODELS REVEALS MUCH COLDER AIR ALOFT RESULTING 
IN SNOW SHOWERS OVER THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS. MOST OF THESE MODEL 
DISCREPANCIES ARE THE RESULT OF THEIR SLIGHTLY DIFFERENT TRACKS OF 
THE UPPER LOW FOR EARLY NEXT WEEK...AND FOR NOW...WILL PLAN TO 
MENTION THE POSSIBILITY OF SOME SNOW SHOWERS FOR EARLY NEXT WEEK. AS 
FOR TEMPS...WILL TREND CLOSE TO THE GFS GUIDANCE NUMBERS THROUGH THE 
EXTENDED PERIOD...WHICH ARE IN GENERAL AGREEMENT WITH THE ENSEMBLE 
MEANS.

&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
340 PM EST TUE NOV 22 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...CONDITIONS NOT LOOKING AS 
POTENT OVERALL FOR THIS EVENING.  STILL ENOUGH STRENGTH IN WIND 
FIELD TO GET FAST WINDS TRANSFERRED TO GROUND VIA THUNDERSTORM 
DOWNDRAFTS.  ALSO ENOUGH SHEAR TO HAVE SOME BOWING LINE SEGMENTS.  AS 
CELLS MOVE TO NORTHEAST...THEY WILL RUN INTO LESS AND LESS 
INSTABILITY AND SHOULD POSE LESS OF A THREAT...WITH DOWNDRAFTS 
BECOMING WEAK AS WELL...AND THEREFORE LESS OUTFLOW WINDS.  

STILL LOOKS LIKE THERE WILL BE TWO WAVES OF PRECIPITATION LATE THIS 
AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT.  THIS FIRST WAVE THAT IS PASSING THROUGH THE 
WESTERN AREAS NOW MAY END UP BEING THE MORE INTENSE. BY THE TIME
THE SECOND ONE ARRIVES...WE WILL BE PAST PEAK HEATING...BUT ALSO
THIS AREA HAS BEEN IN RELATIVELY STABLE AIR MOST OF THE DAY...DUE
TO THICK CLOUD COVER.

WENT WITH THUNDER FOR EVENING AND JUST SHOWERS LATE TONIGHT.  MOST 
OF THE PRECIP WILL HAVE EXITED BY DAYBREAK WEDNESDAY.
 
.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY)...RIDGING SURFACE AND 
ALOFT MOVES EAST ACROSS THE AREA SATURDAY. COOL NIGHTS WITH WARM 
DAYS AND DRY CONDITIONS. BACKED OFF ON PRECIPITATION FOR SATURDAY. 
FORECAST CONFIDENCE LOWERS DRAMATICALLY FROM SUNDAY INTO NEXT WEEK. 
A SHARP HIGH AMPLITUDE TROUGH IS PROGGED TO DEVELOP THROUGH THE 
NATIONS MIDSECTION. STRENGTH AND LOCATION REMAINS UNCERTAIN. A 
DEVELOPING LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM WILL LIKELY CUT OFF FROM THE NORTHERN 
STREAM AND LINGER IN THE MID SOUTH OR TENNESSEE VALLEY WELL INTO 
NEXT WEEK. UPPER TEMPERATURES IN THE LOW WILL BE COLD ENOUGH FOR 
SOME MIXED PRECIPITATION EARLY NEXT WEEK. AT THIS TIME THE FREEZING 
LEVEL APPEARS TO REMAIN AT OR ABOVE 2800 FEET. FORECAST ADJUSTMENT 
CAN BE EXPECTED WITH THESE LATER PERIODS.

.DISCUSSION...

NOT EXPECTING MUCH INSTABILITY TO BUILD INTO AREA...SHEAR WILL BE
INCREASING...BUT MAIN SHEAR WILL MOVE TO THE NORTH. SPC
PARAMETERS...SCP STP SIGSVR ALL SHOW SOME SIGNS OF LIFE IN THE
MODELS...BUT ARE GENERALLY DEPENDING ON SHEAR VALUES. CAPES
GENERALLY EXPECTED TO STAY <=500 J/KG THIS AFTERNOON ACROSS THE
AREA...SO DEFINITELY LOW-TOPPED CONVECTION...AND WOULD THINK SEVERE
THREAT IS MAINLY FROM WIND. CAN'T RULE OUT A BRIEF WEAK TORNADO
SPIN-UP...BUT WOULD THINK MAINLY FAST WINDS ALOFT BROUGHT TO GROUND
IN RAIN CORE DOWNDRAFT...WHICH THEN TRANSLATES TO DAMAGING OUTFLOW
WIND WILL BE MAIN THREAT. BETTER THREATS SOUTH-THROUGH WEST-THROUGH
NORTHWEST PARTS OF CWA.

JUST SOME MINOR TWEAKING TO GRIDS WITH DEW POINTS AND CURRENT TEMPS
RUNNING A LITTLE BEHIND. DID NOT ADJUST HIGH TEMP FOR THIS AFTERNOON.

FXUS64 KMRX 220905
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
405 AM EST TUE NOV 22 2011

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS A 
LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM CENTERED OVER CENTRAL ARKANSAS...WITH ITS 
ASSOCIATED WARM FRONT EXTENDING NORTHEASTWARD ACROSS THE OHIO RIVER 
VALLEY. AREA RADARS REVEAL SCATTERED STRONG TO SEVERE CONVECTION 
OVER THE LOWER MS RIVER VALLEY...WITH ONLY PATCHY DRIZZLE OVER THE 
TN RIVER VALLEY. MODELS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THE PROGRESSION 
OF THIS LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM TODAY AND TONIGHT...AND INDICATE THAT 
THE CENTER OF THE LOW WILL MOVE NORTHEASTWARD ACROSS THE OHIO RIVER 
VALLEY...WHILE ITS ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT MOVES ACROSS THE TN RIVER 
VALLEY. MODELS AGREE THAT MOST OF THE CONVECTION AHEAD OF THIS COLD 
FRONT WILL STAY WEST OF THE FORECAST AREA UNTIL MID TO LATE 
AFTERNOON. MODEL SOUNDINGS REVEAL A STRONG VEERING VERTICAL WIND 
PROFILE DEVELOPING OVER THE FORECAST AREA BETWEEN 18 AND 00Z...WITH 
STRONG 0-1 KM HELICITY VALUES (AROUND 300-400 M2/S2) SUPPORTIVE OF 
THE DEVELOPMENT OF ISOLATED TORNADOES. THE MAIN POSSIBLE LIMITING 
FACTOR FOR SEVERE TSTORMS OVER THE FORECAST AREA INVOLVES THE AMOUNT 
OF INSTABILITY. NAM AND GFS MODELS STILL SHOW SOME DISAGREEMENTS 
WITH THE AMOUNT OF INSTABILITY DEVELOPING OVER THE FORECAST AREA 
THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING...BUT THE STRONG WIND DYNAMICS EXPECTED 
WITH THIS FRONT SHOULD HELP TO SUSTAIN AN EASTBOUND SQUALL LINE OF 
STRONG TO SEVERE TSTORMS ORIGINATING FROM MIDDLE TN. WILL PLAN TO 
MENTION THE POSSIBILITY OF DAMAGING WINDS AND LOCALLY HEAVY RAINFALL 
IN THE ZONE FORECASTS...AND WILL CONTINUE TO MENTION THESE THREATS 
(AS WELL AS POSSIBLE ISOLATED TORNADOES) IN THE HAZARDOUS WEATHER 
OUTLOOK. AS FOR TEMPS...GFS AND NAM GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE IN GOOD 
AGREEMENT FOR TODAY AND TONIGHT...AND LOOK REASONABLE.

.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY THROUGH MONDAY)...UPPER TROUGH BEHIND THE 
FRONT IS EXPECTED TO TRACK THROUGH THE REGION ON WEDNESDAY. WILL 
KEEP THE CHANCE POPS GOING WITH THE HIGHEST CHANCES IN THE NORTH.  
RIDGE BUILDS IN BRINGING DRY WEATHER FOR THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. A 
FRONT TRACKS THROUGH THE AREA ON LATE SATURDAY INTO SUNDAY...WILL 
KEEP CHANCE POPS GOING FOR BOTH PERIODS. UPPER LOW FOLLOWS ON SUNDAY 
NIGHT AND MONDAY...CONTINUING THE CHANCE FOR PRECIPITATION. COOLER 
AIR PUSHING IN BEHIND THE FRONT COULD CAUSE RAIN TO CHANGE TO SNOW 
ON SUNDAY NIGHT...BUT MAINLY ACROSS THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS.

NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
300 PM EST MON NOV 21 2011

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...WEAK SHORT WAVE ENERGY 
CURRENTLY IMPACTING MUCH OF THE FORECAST AREA WILL SHIFT SLOWLY 
NORTHEAST AWAY FROM THE AREA TONIGHT WITH ADDITIONAL RIPPLES WAVING 
ALONG THE OHIO VALLEY FRONTAL BOUNDARY. TRIED TO STAY WITH THE MODEL 
TREND WHICH INDICATES REDUCED PROBABILITY FOR RAIN ACROSS THE 
SOUTHERN HALF OF THE FORECAST AREA TONIGHT AS THE DEEPENING 
SOUTHWESTERN U.S. UPPER LEVEL TROUGH SHIFTS NORTHEAST TOWARD THE 
MISSISSIPPI AND LOWER OHIO VALLEY. KEPT LIKELY POPS NEAR THE 
KENTUCKY BORDER WHERE DEEPER MOISTURE IS PROGGED. THE STRONG STORM 
SYSTEM WITH ASSOCIATED SURFACE LOW PRESSURE WILL SHIFT INTO THE OHIO 
VALLEY DURING THE DAY PULLING A WELL DEFINED COLD FRONT TOWARD THE 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS. INSTABILITY WILL BE MARGINAL AHEAD OF THE 
FRONT BUT BULK SHEAR SHOULD POP INTO THE 40 TO 50 KT RANGE WHICH MAY 
HELP TO GENERATE A LINE OF STRONG TO SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS. TRIED TO 
KEEP POPS RATHER LOW DURING THE DAY TUESDAY AS PREFERRED NAM MODEL 
INDICATES A SLOWER EASTWARD PROGRESSION OF FRONTAL SYSTEM. 
DOWNSLOPING ACROSS EAST CENTRAL AND NORTHEASTERN TENNESSEE MAY EVEN 
ALLOW FOR A FEW PEAKS OF SUNSHINE DURING THE DAY. STAYED WITH 
CATEGORICAL POPS FOR THE BIG FROPA TUESDAY NIGHT. BY WEDNESDAY 
MODELS STILL SHOW SOME TRAILING MOISTURE AND LIFT IN THE BACK SIDE 
OF DEEP EASTERN STATES TROUGH SO KEPT A HIGH CHANCE THROUGH SLIGHT 
CHANCE POP GOING FROM NORTHEAST TO SOUTHWEST ACROSS THE FORECAST 
AREA WITH MOST OF THE REGION DRY BY AFTERNOON. STAYED CLOSER TO 
MIDLER MIN TEMPS UNDER BLANKET OF CLOUDS AND MILD DEWPOINTS TONIGHT 
AND WENT CLOSER TO WARMER MAX TEMPS ON TUESDAY AS STRONG SOUTHERLY 
FLOW KICKS IN AHEAD OF LATE DAY/EVENING ARRIVING COLD FRONT. STAYED 
PRETTY CLOSE TO GUIDANCE BLEND TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY.    

.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY)...RIDGING SURFACE AND 
ALOFT PRODUCING MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES AND A WARMING TREND THROUGH 
FRIDAY NIGHT. ANOTHER STORM SYSTEM WILL MOVE INTO THE REGION OVER 
THE WEEKEND. MODELS ARE IN DISAGREEMENT IN THE STRENGTH AND LOCATION 
OF THE UPPER TROUGH WITH CONFIDENCE LOW TOWARDS THE END OF THE 
FORECAST PERIOD. HAVE LEANED TOWARD A ECMWF SOLUTION. SCATTERED 
CONVECTION BECOMES POSSIBLE SATURDAY WITH INCREASED MOISTURE AND 
INSTABILITY. A VIGOROUS COLD FRONT IS PROGGED TO MOVE THROUGH THE 
AREA ON SUNDAY. WIDESPREAD CONVECTION CAN BE EXPECTED WITH THIS 
SYSTEM THOU TIMING IS STILL VERY MUCH IN QUESTION. THICKNESS VALUES 
FALL HARD BEHIND THE FRONT. PRECIPITATION WILL LIKELY CHANGE TO SNOW 
BEHIND THE FRONT. TEMPERATURES WILL BE BELOW NORMAL EARLY NEXT WEEK.

MORE SOUTHWESTERLY TONIGHT...IN RESPONSE TO AN AMPLIFYING TROUGH 
OVER THE SOUTHERN PLAINS. THIS SOUTHWEST UPPER-LEVEL FLOW WILL THEN 
PUSH THE SURFACE FRONTAL BOUNDARY FURTHER NORTH AS A WARM FRONT... 
WITH THE COVERAGE OF CONVECTION EXPECTED TO TEMPORARILY DECREASE. 
MODELS INDICATE THAT A MARGINALLY UNSTABLE AIR MASS WILL DEVELOP 
TODAY AND TONIGHT OVER THE TN RIVER VALLEY...SO WILL INCLUDE A 
MENTION OF TSTORMS FOR BOTH TODAY AND TONIGHT. AS FOR TEMPS...GFS 
AND NAM GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT FOR TODAY AND 
TONIGHT...AND LOOK REASONABLE.

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...A SHORT-WAVE WILL MOVE QUICKLY 
NORTHEAST ACROSS THE OHIO AND TENNESSEE VALLEYS LATE TUESDAY AND 
TUESDAY NIGHT. ASSOCIATED JET WILL PLACE THE FORECAST AREA UNDER 
MODERATELY STRONG DIVERGENCE ALOFT. DECENT AGEOSTROPHIC CIRCULATION 
WILL HELP MAINTAIN FRONTOGENETIC FORCING ALONG A FRONT THAT MOVES 
THROUGH THE AREA LATE FRIDAY AND FRIDAY NIGHT. MODELS SHOW CAPES OF 
300-500 J/KG WHICH WILL BE ENOUGH TO PRODUCE WIDESPREAD SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ALONG AND AHEAD OF THE BOUNDARY. STRONG BOUNDARY-MID 
LEVEL WINDS TO PRODUCE A THREAT OF DAMAGING WINDS ALONG THE LINE OF 
CONVECTION WITH THE MAIN CONCERN ALONG AND WEST AND SOUTH OF 
INTERSTATE 40.

SYSTEM EXITS THE REGION BY WEDNESDAY WITH RIDING SURFACE AND ALOFT 
PRODUCING MOSTLY CLEAR SKY FOR THURSDAY AND FIRST HALF OF FRIDAY. 
ANOTHER STORM SYSTEM WILL MOVE INTO THE AREA AT THE END OF THE 
EXTENDED. MODELS ARE IN DISAGREEMENT IN THE STRENGTH AND LOCATION OF 
THE UPPER TROUGH WITH CONFIDENCE LOW. WILL CALL FOR INCREASING 
CHANCE OF PRECIPITATION SATURDAY AND SUNDAY ALONG AND AHEAD OF A 
COLD FRONT. FAIRLY CHILLY AIR BEHIND THE FRONTAL BOUNDARY. GENERALLY 
WENT COLDER THAN MEX MOS GUIDANCE FOR SUNDAY.
&&

RISEN WELL INTO THE 50S...AND MOS HAS HAD A COOL BIAS FOR MIN TEMPS
LATELY. THUS...I STAYED AT LEAST A FEW DEGREES ABOVE THE COOLER GFS
MOS MINS...GOING WITH OR JUST ABOVE NAM MOS MINS.

MONDAY...HIGHER NAM MOS POPS ARE OKAY IF THERE IS INDEED MORE
SHORTWAVE ENERGY EMBEDDED INTO THE W-SW FLOW ALOFT. THE ACTUAL
FRONT WILL AT LEAST JUSTIFY HIGH POPS FOR NRN PLATEAU AND SW VA/NE
TN AREAS. I SEE A POTENTIAL LULL IN CONVECTIVE PRECIPITATION FOR
MONDAY NIGHT...AS FRONT LIFTS NORTH INTO THE SRN OHIO VALLEY. 

FOR TUESDAY...SURFACE LOW DEVELOPS ON COLD FRONT TO OUR WEST...SO
EXPECT CONVECTION TO BE DEVELOPING AND APPROACHING FROM THE WEST BY
THE AFTERNOON. THIS SHOULD LEAD TO THE MORE SIGNIFICANT RAINS AND
BETTER CHANCES OF THUNDERSTORMS...ESPECIALLY INTO TUESDAY NIGHT.

FOR TEMPS...OTHER THAN ADJUSTMENTS ON MINS...MOS MAX TEMPS WERE
CLOSE OVERALL AND FOLLOWED.


.LONG TERM...(TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...LIKELY POPS WERE
APPLIED TO THE FORECAST ON TUESDAY NIGHT AS SHOWERS AND POSSIBLY
THUNDERSTORMS PROGRESS EAST ACROSS THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS IN
ASSOCIATION WITH OHIO VALLEY MID LATITUDE CYCLONE. THE FEATURE
EXITS THROUGH NEW ENGLAND DURING THE DAY WEDNESDAY BUT SOME
TRAILING SHORT WAVE ENERGY AND ASSOCIATED MOISTURE KEEP GENERALLY
SMALL POPS FOR SHOWERS GOING MAINLY DURING THE MORNING. A NICE DRY
PERIOD FOLLOWS WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT AS AN AMPLIFIED
UPPER LEVEL RIDGE MAKES ITS WAY SLOWLY EAST FROM THE ROCKIES TO THE
EAST COAST. DEEP UPPER TROUGH ARRIVES IN THE MISSISSIPPI VALLEY
LATER IN THE DAY SATURDAY WITH A SMALL CHANCE FOR SHOWERS SATURDAY
WITH INCREASING PROBABILITY OF RAIN SATURDAY NIGHT INTO SUNDAY AS
THE STRONG STORM SYSTEM PRESSES SLOWLY ACROSS THE MID SOUTH. STAYED
RELATIVELY CLOSE TO NEW MEX MOS GUIDANCE IF NOT A DEGREE OR TWO
WARMER THROUGH MUCH OF THE LONG TERM.

ACTIVITY IS ANTICIPATED MONDAY NIGHT. FAIRLY STRONG LOW PRESSURE 
SYSTEM WILL MOVE ACROSS THE OHIO VALLEY TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND NIGHT 
WITH ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT MOVING ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. STRONG 
JET DYNAMICS WILL MAINTAIN STRONG FRONTO-GENETIC FORCING OVER THE 
FORECAST AREA TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND NIGHT. WILL CALL FOR WIDESPREAD 
SHOWERS WITH EMBEDDED THUNDER.

SYSTEM PULLS EAST FOR WEDNESDAY WITH GRADUAL CLEARING OF LOW CLOUDS. 
FOR THURSDAY AND FIRST HALF OF FRIDAY RIDGING SURFACE AND ALOFT WILL 
PRODUCE MOSTLY CLEAR SKY AND NEAR SEASONAL TEMPERATURES. FOR LATE 
FRIDAY AND FRIDAY NIGHT...SURFACE RIDGING MOVES EAST WITH INCREASING 
SOUTHERLY FLOW INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY AND SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS. 
WINDY CONDITIONS ANTICIPATED...ESPECIALLY FOR THE HIGHER 
ELEVATIONS...SATURDAY AND SATURDAY EVENING AS PRESSURE GRADIENT 
TIGHTENS. GFS/ECMWF ARE IN PRETTY GOOD AGREEMENT IN PULLING A STRONG 
COLD FRONT THROUGH THE AREA LATE SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT. FAIRLY

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS 
HIGH PRESSURE CENTERED ALONG THE MID ATLANTIC COAST...WHICH WAS 
PRODUCING A SOUTHERLY WIND FLOW OVER THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN 
REGION. LATEST SATELLITE IMAGERY REVEALS THAT SOME ISENTROPIC LIFT 
FROM THESE SOUTHERLY WINDS WAS CREATING AN EXPANDING AREA OF MID- 
LEVEL CLOUDS OVER NORTHERN GA AND NORTHERN AL. THESE CLOUDS SHOULD 
COVER AT LEAST SOUTHEAST TN AND SOUTHWEST NC THIS MORNING...SO WILL 
PLAN TO BE MORE PESSIMISTIC WITH THE SKY CONDITION WORDING IN THE 
FORECAST. SOUTHWESTERLY WINDS ARE PROGGED TO STRENGTHEN TODAY OVER 
THE FORECAST AREA...WHICH SHOULD CONTINUE TO RESULT IN A MOISTENING 
OF THE LOCAL AIR MASS INTO TONIGHT. NAM MODEL INDICATES SOME LIGHT 
PRECIP AMOUNTS TONIGHT AS ISENTROPIC LIFT INCREASES OVER THE 
REGION...BUT WILL NOT MENTION ANY PRECIP FOR NOW SINCE THE GFS MODEL 
REMAINS DRY TONIGHT. AS FOR TEMPS...GFS AND NAM GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE 
IN GOOD AGREEMENT FOR TODAY AND TONIGHT...BUT SHOW DISCREPANCIES 
WITH MAXES OVER SOUTHEAST TN TODAY DUE TO CLOUD COVER DIFFERENCES. 
FOR NOW...WILL PLAN TO LEAN TOWARDS THE WARMER GFS NUMBERS FOR 
TODAY...SINCE TEMPS ARE STILL RELATIVELY WARM THIS MORNING OVER 
SOUTHEAST TN (COMPARED TO THE REST OF THE FORECAST AREA).


.LONG TERM...(SUNDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...MODELS REMAIN IN GENERAL 
AGREEMENT WITH OVERALL PATTERN THROUGH THE LONG TERM. SERIES OF 
SHORT WAVE TROUGHS STILL ON TRACK TO AFFECT THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN 
REGION BY LATE SUNDAY...CULMINATING A MORE AMPLIFIED WAVE SWINGING 
THROUGH THE AREA BY TUESDAY NIGHT. THIS FEATURE PUSHES SURFACE FRONT 
WELL SOUTH OF OUR AREA ALONG WITH ACCOMPANYING PRECIP. UPPER RIDGE 
BUILDS IN THROUGH THE BALANCE OF THE LONG TERM WITH TEMPS REBOUNDING 
TO BACK ABOVE CLIMO BY LATE IN THE LONG TERM. FOR TEMPS...GENERALLY 
DID NOT DEVIATE MUCH FROM MAV/MEX GUIDANCE.


&&
